ResponsesInList.Title: why the home page is different from others?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, im new at moodle. I created a new theme and changed the header.html to put a flash header in it. When i publish it, i only get to see the flash header in the inner pages, but the home page doesn't seem to read it. Is that possible? Does anyone know what may cause that? Thanks a lot!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: why the home page is different from others?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, but you'll need to change some code in your theme/ header.html file. You will see (about line 21) if ($home) { // This is what gets printed on the home page only and about line 27 <?php } else if ($heading) { // This is what gets printed on any other page with a heading If you make sure that the text in the else if ($heading) section matches that in the if ($home) section, your flash header will work on all pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: why the home page is different from others?
ResponsesInList.Text: Personally, I always remove that bit from my header.html completely and have one header for all pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: [ADAPTABLE] RTL DESIGN PROBLEMS

Is there any way around for me to make it in the middle again ? Look forward for your all support on this case and thank you ....

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [ADAPTABLE] DESIGN PROBLEMS
ResponsesInList.Text:
Just align the text to left or center using the editor buttons or add: 
```text
style="text-align: right;"
```
 to the paragraph. Notice that Adaptable is not tested with RTL languages. Some parts could not display the content correctly.

ResponsesInList.Title: How can I copy and paste from MSWord without distorting the content in Adaptable theme?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Good day, Fernando, as I can copy and paste text
from MSWord with its attributes to a text box moodle, without that the content
being deformed. I searched plugins Atto, but do not work. There is some code format html that I can use
for this purpose?. In this case, it is necessary make a differentiation between
H4 and H3 or is the same for both? or must necessarily be done with a plugin. Or is there some method practical to copy and
paste from MSWord without distorting the content when is extensive. Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I copy and paste from MSWord without distorting the content in Adaptable theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Diana, As you may see from the top of this particular thread, this thread has now been closed due to the size and a new Adaptable thread set up with several subcategories. However, I don't think this is an Adaptable (or even a theme) issue anyway, but one with the text editors generally. It is a known consequence of using MSWord that MSWord adds a whole raft of its own formatting which can often distort or even break webpages (not just Moodle!). You could try the clear formatting tool in Atto, or you could try copying and pasting the text via a plain text editor such as Notepad and then into Moodle, but you may lose some (or all) of your desired formatting - you can replace it using the Atto formatting tools to create web-safe formatting. Richard (Edited by Mary Evans - to split and change subject title - original submission Monday, 25 April 2016, 11:33 PM)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I copy and paste from MSWord without distorting the content in Adaptable theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Richard, I had not given me realize that this thread was closed. Regards. (Edited by Mary Evans - to split and change title - original submission Monday, 25 April 2016, 11:52 PM)

ResponsesInList.Title: How to get URL of a resource within the pix theme directory?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I have a PHP file where I want to get the URL of an mp4 file I have placed in my themes' pix directory (theme/name/pix/home/video.mp4), then I'll pass that URL into the context array for use in my mustache template. So much like you'd use $OUTPUT->pix_url('imagename', 'theme_name') and it returns the URL of an image. I've also tried the following, but I don't know if it has the correct parameters, it creates the URL: background.mp4 but I've tried removing 'pix' from the path and it still doesn't work. 
```text
moodle_url::make_pluginfile_url($context->id, 'theme_name', 'pix', null, '/home/', 'video.mp4')
```
 Neither method works for the mp4 file, it just returns a 'image not found' error message and then inserts the filename.mp4.error file within site data, albeit within the correct directory, so it is looking in the right place for it, I'm guessing it just has an issue handling anything other than images. I've been struggling for a few hours and I'm sure it must be something simple haha. Thanks, Nathan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get URL of a resource within the pix theme directory?
ResponsesInList.Text: File serving in a theme eg: https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/blob/MOODLE_30/layout/tiles/header.php#L38 https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/blob/MOODLE_30/classes/toolbox.php#L59-L95 https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/blob/MOODLE_30/lib.php#L53-L54 https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/blob/MOODLE_30/lib.php#L84-L149

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get URL of a resource within the pix theme directory?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get URL of a resource within the pix theme directory?
ResponsesInList.Text: I know!  But it is an example of how to serve non-image files in a theme!  Hence the reply with the words 'File serving in a theme' and list of links that should help you to adapt that solution to your problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to get URL of a resource within the pix theme directory?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nathan, For your Information pix_url has been depreciated since Moodle 3.4 it has been replaced by image_url or icon _url depending on its usage.. In your case it may be a better idea to create a new directory of its own and call it something like media ? So the URL would be ... $video_url => new moodle_url('/theme/theme_name/media/video.mp4'); so your template context would be... video_url = $video_url; sorry if template notation is wrong I have forgotten for the moment what the correct way is!!! Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Creating a Seamless Cross-Site Look-and-Feel?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, as discussed in another thread , I would like to create an additional commerce site that will accompany my main Moodle installation. That external site will handle ordering and payment for courses and will be based on Drupal or WordPress (or whatever). I am now wondering how to keep the design efforts manageable. Ideally, I would like to create a (more or less) seamless look-and-feel regarding the overall design, without having to work on two completely different codes. I have a lot of experience developing themes for Drupal, but have only recently started to look into Moodle. Can anybody offer any hints as to how to proceed? E.g., there's a base theme for Drupal that's based on Bootstrap... and Moodle's Boost theme (as well as the Adaptable theme, which I'm currently using) are based on Bootstrap, as well. Does anybody happen to know, if the HTML/ CSS structures are similar enough, so that, say, a Bootstrap setup can be simply copied from one page to another? Any help will be much appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Seamless Cross-Site Look-and-Feel?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, what version of Moodle please? What version of Bootstrap does the the Drupal base theme use? What Moodle theme developer documentation ( https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Themes ) have you read?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Seamless Cross-Site Look-and-Feel?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the quick reply. Currently, I'm using Moodle 3.3 with the most recent Adaptable theme installed. I did quite a few modifications in the code, after having read the documentation about overriding the renderers. So far, that worked pretty well. I have to say, I feel more confident editing Drupal templates than Moodle code. I am willing, of course, to dig myself into this, but have been hoping that there would be a way for... dunno, creating a Bootstrap configuration in Drupal and then copying it over to Moodle, while doing only minimal adjustments. Not sure, if that is even possible. The Drupal base theme I was talking about is based on Bootstrap 3, but there might be other possibilities. I would really like to use Drupal, as I feel most confident there, but have not made a final decision. Also, I'd be willing to switch from Adaptable to, say, Boost, if that would simplify matters.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Seamless Cross-Site Look-and-Feel?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, Adaptable is Bootstrap 2.3.2 based (as well as many others like Clean and the ones I maintain: Essential, Campus and Shoelace). Boost is based upon Moodle's alpha port of the BS 4 version of the framework. Bootstrapbase (theme and parent of Clean) has its origin from the contributed Bootstrap theme ( https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_bootstrap ) which is now BS 3 and along with my Shoehorn ( https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_shoehorn ) appears to be no longer maintained. Classes wise, BS4 is similar to BS3 but uses SASS instead of LESS.  BS2.3.2 uses an older grid system.  However as BS 4 progresses I'm not sure how aligned the versions are between the BS 4 distribution and the one in Moodle core. So, really a matter of what you want to change and what you feel comfortable with. In reality I think it is understanding Moodle Themes that will be harder than applying the specifics of a given framework version API.  And that just requires time and effort.  The framework is not the solution it is just the tool used in the solution.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Creating a Seamless Cross-Site Look-and-Feel?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you want to add a shopping cart to moodle you have several options: - Add Paypal as enrollment method and use moodle itself to sell the courses - Use Joomla as a shopping through Joomdle - Use Wordpress as a shopping cart using Edwiser bridge Drupal had a bridge but now is totally outdated for both, Drupal and Moodle. All the solutions above are able to sell the course (or bundle of courses) and enroll the user automatically.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Flexibase] Onwards | What are you doing with this?
ResponsesInList.Text: There's no stable child theme for Flexibase at the moment, but the theme_components idea I worked on in an earlier version is still available from my github, so features such as awesomebar can (fairly) easily be added into most other themes. There were a few other features added into recent versions though - such as additional block regions (e.g. there's an 'alerts' region at the top of the page, which hides the block header by default - this came from a request to be able to allow anyone with front page editing rights to be able to post alerts, but there is no way of splitting the theme capabilities, and the alerts that most themes - including flexibase - have are theme settings, so can only be set by Site admins). Over the last 6 months there have also been a number of bug fixes highlighted by user testing. Oh and the big one - which I'm still not entirely convinced by myself and may remove - I added a separate page for blocks (which is set as the default, so its where the 'Add a block' appears) which is aimed at giving people the option of moving towards a 'blockless' main page - although the theme still has the huge range of custom block regions to give that flexibility of design over to the course creator. I plan on looking at Flexibase for 3.2 through October, so any suggestions or comments from anyone about features (existing or suggested), likes and dislikes, or bugs and improvements, will definitely be considered during that time! While it's perhaps not one of the 'big 3' themes, Flexibase has far exceeded my expectations as what was originally planned as an experimental theme to look at the use of the flexbox layout methods. I will be continuing to support it into at least 3.2 and probably 3.3, but probably wont do any more new feature development on it after a 3.2 release in November/December (for example the original flexi_ii theme hasn't been officially supported since Moodle2.1, but I was still unofficially supporting people using it on Moodle2.9 up until earlier this year). I'm hoping then to apply some of what I learned in creating Flexibase and create at least two new themes based around the new Moodle3.2 theme and the flex layouts - one to be quite basic, simply applying flex layouts (BS4 has a setting that simply enables flex as an alternative layout grid, so I've been playing with that a bit), and the other to be a kind of Flexibase2 with the additional features. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text:
We are putting together a moodle site for college funding projects, but
everything in Moodle references "courses."  I've seen other sites with
non-standard labels. Has anyone heard of a mod for customizing 
Moodle terminology - labels/headers, without having to hack the code? 
Our ITS dept is not keen on changing core code,..we are also willing to
collaborate on writing such a mod....if one doesn't already exist. Thanks. Jean Hardy Central Piedmont Community College, NC, USA

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: You can change any text that appears anywhere in Moodle, by customizing the English language pack.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you.  This is extremely helpful. I will take a look at both options and I appreciate your steerage. Jean

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: Beginning from the main page, you can go to Configurations - Languages - Compare and edit language in use . Moodle.php have the most references to "courses" and you can edit it. It is easier that php code. First of all, make  a backup. Then, you can use "Find" or (be carefull) "Find and replace" of your browser. Good luck!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: editing the lag packs have been easy enough. a bit time consuming, but straight forward. one limitation i see is that the "/course" directory structure is in place. can that be easily changed to something less specific? perhaps "/content" or similar.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm looking to do pretty much the same thing - the terminology 'course' means something completely different to our tutors, and as we also use Moodle as student intranet now there are areas for information that shouldn't be described as courses. I'm sure I can make the language pack edit without any problems, but was wondering if there are any knock-on effects (eg if we backup then restore a course to a different site). I'm thinking ahead to move to 2.0 where I'd want to build the new site from scratch then port in resources (assuming the compatibility issues get fixed). Having 'courses' that are information rather than learning focused also prompts the thought - couldn't these be labelled in Moodle course settings the same way that roles can be renamed (eg Librarian instead of Lecturer)? Make the content suit the context !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: if there are any knock-on effects (eg if we backup then restore a course to a different site). That's an interesting question I hadn't thought of - if you edit the language in one Moodle and then backup and restore a course in another Moodle what happens to the language? I would be pretty certain it would revert back to the default language of the new Moodle, ie, without the changes done in the original one. I'd like to know for sure though.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't even think about renaming the course folder in the Moodle codebase to something else. Just live with course in the URL .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customized Terminology

ResponsesInList.Title: Now Available:  Easy Enrollment Plugin as part of Fordson Theme Set
ResponsesInList.Text: We just got approval for our easy Enrollment Add-on for the Fordson theme.  This add-on will work with any theme but is integrated to make things super easy in the Fordson theme. The easy enrollment plugin allows teachers to use 6 digit codes to enroll in courses and groups within courses.  Once the Easy Enrollment plugin is activated,  the Fordson theme displays an enrollment form for students on the homepage as well as an easy to find button on course pages to show the class enrollment codes to teachers. https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=84 The Easy Enrollment plugin will also generate and read QR codes if you have SSL activated on the server .  This is a cool feature if you are working with kindergartners or really young students.  The teacher can print out the QR code and walk around the room and wave the paper in front of the computer camera and instantly enroll the students. Easy Enrollment Plugin https://moodle.org/plugins/enrol_easy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 3.2 - Add value on Flat navigation
ResponsesInList.Text: Gareth - Yes it's currently only a Boost (and child) thing and relates to the mustache template that renders the new navigation panel. Daniel - you would need to make changes to the flat_navigation.mustache file to make use of that additional value being passed. Probably inside a conditional mustache block to determine whether the value exists in that context . You should also probably do this in a child theme or clone of Boost rather than in Boost itself (normal caveats around editing core theme/component etc)

ResponsesInList.Title: Changing the color of "You are not logged in"...
ResponsesInList.Text: The background color I've chosen in my modified theme has completely hidden the "You are not logged in" (and "You are logged in as") text that appears in the header. Which file has the color settings for those phrases (I know styles_color. css is the obvious choice, but couldn't find anything in there relating to color of login text. I recursively grepped all the files in the entire Moodle folder and actually found the text of the phrases, but again, nothing about color there. And I know I could put it in a table row and fill in that row with a nice contrasting background color, but I really need to change the text, not add a long narrow bar across my theme. Anyone know where I can change the color of those login phrases? Thanks. John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the color of "You are not logged in"...
ResponsesInList.Text:
Class .logininfo (and .logininfo a for the actual link). There is no color setting for this class in Moodle Themes , so you'll just have to add a line in one of your own theme's CSS files, e.g.: 
```text
.logininfo {color:#FFFFFF;}
```
 Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the color of "You are not logged in"...
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry for the delay in getting back to you.  I've been away. I amended the code in the fw_colour.css .loginbox .header { border-color:#C6BDA8; } .loginbox .content { border-color:#C6BDA8; } .logininfo {color:#FFFFFF;} .logininfo a:link, .logininfo a:visited  {text-decoration: underline; color:#FFFFFF;}

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove content in front page of custome theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Crazy Coder, Please read https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=333733 and then we may be able to help you. Thanks Lazydaisy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove content in front page of custome theme
ResponsesInList.Text: I am using Moodle 3.1+.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Remove content in front page of custome theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Crazy Coder, The problem with Moodle is that the front page is the index.php and as such you cannot do much with it. So the best way is to use a simple layout that has no block regions in it unless it is a custom one. You also need to make sure that the Frontpage settings is empty of content before login and also after login if you do not want any content visible on the front page when a user is logged in?. If you take a look at the frontpage.php layout file of my GoLogo theme, you will see I have added lots of customisation mainly hand coded for speed as it is just an experiment. The side blocks are hidden but still accessible by the Admin User. Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do I add a theme
ResponsesInList.Text: You'll need to copy the new theme into a subdirectory of the moodle/theme directory. See http://docs.moodle.org/en/Themes#Installing_a_theme .

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Dream Theme ...
ResponsesInList.Text: OK ... I guess I'll be the one to ask. Is there anyway that we can have a centralized theme, available to anyone, that can be used with Moodle and MediaWiki ( and possibly Elgg ) like there is here on Moodle.org? I have admired the Moodle home theme ever since I was introduced to Moodle, way back to 1.5. I have tried to duplicate something similar to what is here ( except with my own colors, graphics and format ), however it ended up being a total mess and I gave up. Next, I also love the monobook theme of Wikipedia as well. So I tried to modify Mediawiki AND Moodle to work together with the monobook theme and again what a mess ... Can anyone see frustration in this man's voice? Then to really mess with my brain, Martin seemlessly adds Mediawiki to the Moodle Homepage and I thought my G-d... how much more torture can this man put us through? He's toying with my brain, making all the little voices that talk to me, taunt me by saying if he can do it why can't I do it??? So here's my thoughts ... as a community ... let's work together to make a theme that integrates Moodle, MediaWiki, and Elgg into ONE centralized theme ( similar to Moodle.org ) that can be modified and altered as needed. It's either that or we subscribe to the lithium-for-sale-online-store and use medication to silence the little voices. All kidding aside. The BIGGEST drawback to Moodle, IMHO , is the inability to modify the way Moodle looks and feels to the users. I am not a programmer, however I have ALWAYS been able to modify the programs I use to achieve my desired goals. Not so with Moodle. Pointing to the "Theme" section of the site is useless because after over 8 years of Moodle development there are less than 40 themes in the archives. Not a very good track record IMHO.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Dream Theme ...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey, Lee, I agree pretty much with the compliments on the look and feel for the Moodle/MediaWiki integration. I think it takes a lot of effort and know how to be able to pull something like that and I've been a bit frustrated with my own inability to just jump in and modify at will. But we can be thankful that others have put in the effort and the work needed and if we treat them nicely maybe they'll share... eh, whaddaya think? I hope so, my brain is mushed from all the tweaking of .php file settings etc. With regards, J.Bowks wlbd.org

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Dream Theme ...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee, i will respectfully disagree with one point. What I love about Moodle is the ability to customise it's look and feel. I have built sites where you cant tell Moodle aprt from the website it was linked from. The CSS really allows you to control just about anything. That being said, I also recognise the fact it takes some getting used to and familiarisation. Ways to better this process (and I cant think of any easy ones off the top of my head) would be a good start. JR

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Clean theme : Request to upgread Bootstrap 3
ResponsesInList.Text: As I understand the previous discussions around this, there are no plans to upgrade Clean to use Bootstrap3. There is a theme_bootstrap, maintained by Bas Brands, which is based on Bootstrap3 which can be used as a parent theme (and is used for several themes based on BS3 such as flexibase - I can't remember whether Elegance uses that as a parent theme or is a standalone BS3 theme). Moodle3.2 and 3.3 introduced a new core theme (Boost) which has jumped directly to Bootstrap4. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: WOFF2 support in themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Themers, I'm pleased to announce that MDL-49074 has now been integrated and is now a part of core: 2.8.5+ (Build: 20150313) - 2014111005.01 2.7.7+ (Build: 20150313) - 2014051207.01 MDL-46728 was integrated some weeks ago for M2.9. This means that WOFF2 fonts can now be supported in themes using the 'font:theme' syntax in your CSS files ( How to add custom fonts in a theme ).  Please ensure you update your Moodle to the version stated above or greater to make use of the functionality. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 回复: Re: 回复: Re: Problem with uploaded Themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, this is difficult to explain. In 1.9, themes started using print containers to designate the headers for the homepage and all other pages. <?php print_container_start(true, '', 'header-home'); ?> This PHP will not work in older versions of Moodle and your theme will stop Moodle from loading beyond that line. You want to look for such PHP references, and swap them out for their HTML counterpart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Theme Ownership
ResponsesInList.Text: There are 3 scenarios I'm looking to question the 'ownership' of a Moodle theme. CSS is code just like PHP or Javascript so if I create a theme for Moodle and distribute it I must release it under the GPL license therefore: 1. I create a theme, never share it, distribute it, or release it. It is a theme only available to me. Its mine, all mine and nobody can steal the CSS etc... 2. I create a theme and release it to the Moodle community in the theme database released under the GPL license. Released as GPL as its based on Moodle (GPL) code - For example config.php is Moodle code. Its free to everyone, to modify, copy etc... 3. A company creates a theme for a customer, customers pays X amount for the theme. Theme has now been distributed to 5 customers with varying levels of modification. Its been distributed so therefore must be released under GPL? The customer is free to do with it as they like. Im free to take a copy of the CSS and reproduce? ++++ These are purely hypothetical questions which i've asked myself and never been able to work out the answer to. A few people have also asked me similar questions, justlooking for some clarification.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Theme Ownership
ResponsesInList.Text: The way I see it, you can distribute your Moodle Themes anyway you want. Get them licenced under Creative Commons Licence if you wish. This is what most web-designers do to protect their creative work, since I feel theme are works of art. However, if you choose to add a theme to Moodle's theme database, then you have to be prepared to share it under GPL (General Public Licence). Last year I  made a few Moodle themes where the original designs were from Free CSS Webpage Templates, but the owner had licenced then under CCL and refused my request to distribute them under the GPL licence as Moodle themes, so I had to take them off the Moodle Themes' Database . However, the CSS Template is offered FREE to anyone to customize/use it for business or personal websites/and all the designer asks is that you provide a link to their site. What I can't understand is why Moodle are so restrictive in this, as GPL is more to do with software distribution licencing and nothing to do with creative design, which web-design is. I would really like to see it as joint licencing, which seems to be the way most people are moving towards. Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Theme Ownership
ResponsesInList.Text: This has been debated at length in the past. I suggest you find the previous thread(s), which explain why this policy is necessary. OK, to save you Googling: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=121826 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=123915 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=164353 Actually, the really informative thread was http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=135896 themes are no different from any other sort of Moodle plugin in this regard.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it me or FireFox on a PC?
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Eduardo & the list, What theme did you base your development on? The problem seems related to the header style in CSS . I know this might be a point of contention but I recommend that you develop your theme in Firefox and then "test" in IE . The reasons for this are: 1) Firefox is compliant to international web standards and IE is not. Hence, by developing in the correct environment, you ensure that your site is actually web compliant and works in a modern open source browser.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it me or FireFox on a PC?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Werner, I agree with most of your arguments in defense of FireFox. I do exactly that: make my customizations on FF and then test (if I have the time) on MSIE (version 7). Let me add one remark. >1) Firefox is compliant to international web standards and IE is not. This is true. However, I have found that in some circumstances FF is more "tolerant" than MSIE. This means that some pages which contain some (minor) formatting mistakes (CSS or HTML) will nevertheless display fine on FF but the error will show off in MSIE. Here is an example which I came across recently. In a table, I had all rows formatted for text-align:center. Strangely, in FF the text in the top row would be centered as expected, and the other rows too. But, in MSIE, only the top row would be centered, text in the other rows looked as if it was left-aligned. I eventually found out that (in the php file) I had set the width of the cells in the top row at 80px but the cells in the other rows were set at 40px. FF did not mind and centered the other rows centered as the top ones, but MSIE centered the top row OK but centered the other rows within the 40px width , so they looked left-aligned! After I had corrected the php file code and set all cells to 80px, display was fine in both browsers. It's hard to decide which browser's interpretation is "correct" or desirable. On the one hand it's nice that FF is "tolerant" and seems to take the best decisions, on the other hand, MSIE's display points to the inconsistency in the code... Joseph

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all, I'm new to Moodle and have this question: We have a single course, in its own Category, that will be used by more than one company. I can separate each company into its own Group and force them to remain separate, but I would like each company to have their own theme. What I'm asking for is a Group Theme, but I don't think its currently possible. If I could instead assign a preferred user theme with the imported company flat file of users, I thought that might work. We will already be using the flat file to enroll them in the course, assign them to groups and assign roles, so why not define each user's theme there too? We have enabled "allowed user themes," so we could manually set each user's theme, but this would be very time consuming. Is there also a way I can set or define the preferred user theme from a flat file? I tried a column heading of "theme" but it was not recognized, and I was unable to find a list of variables within the Moodle online documentation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is it possible to define a preferred user theme in a flat file?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Jim, Unfortunately, I'm not able to help you on your first three requests because I don't think they are possible. 1.) No group themes 2.) No upload user "theme" option 3.) No "preferred user theme" upload option that I know of. - these are all things that you may want to recommend to the core developers - http://tracker.moodle.og -------- I do have a solution for hiding the user theme preference, though. Add the following to the bottom of a CSS file: body#user-editadvanced #moodle #id_theme { display:none !important; } This will hide the dropdown menu from your users' view. Not the most elegant solution, but a solution nonetheless.

ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi All I can't work out how to get my little set of icons in the right place...! Moodle 1.9 I am trying to get a bunch of icons to sit above and to the right of the "You are logged in as xxxxx" on the home page. Any ideas what I am doing wrong please? d. The relevant chunk of styles_layout. css I've been using is as follows: ```text .headermenu { float:right; text-align:right; margin: 35px 0px 0px 0px; } #header div.icons { width: 300px; height: 26px; position: absolute; top: 10px; ``` ```text ``` And the relevant chunk of the header.html is as follows: ```text

```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS driving me mad!
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, my first suggestion would be that if you want the icons above the 'you are logged in as' then it would be easier to start by putting them before the <?php echo $menu ?> which is the bit that creates that in 1.9. While you can move things around using css, I find it easier to start with them in the order you want them unless there are significant reasons not to (eg. search engine optimization - which shouldn't apply here). You might also want to think about taking them outside the headermenu div completely so that they can be positioned independently of it and so that the headermenu div is just for the headermenu and not including the icons as well. Also, why is there a need to specify the css for div.icons both in #header and in #header2 ? Do you have one or both of these divs which are not shown in the clips you have provided? At the moment I think your .icons css will only be applied when that class falls inside the div id=header or header2 neither of which are shown here. The print_container settings, I believe, create a div #header-home in the case of the clip you have shown and so would not apply the css you have created. HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS driving me mad!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, You are so right about header-home which is what I saw straight away when I read the email about this. I've just read your comment now and pleased to see you noticed that too! That was one of the first things I learned about Moodle 1.9. The fact it had two different selectors for the header. The times I got that header wrong! LOL It's good to see this code again though, it brings back some happy memories. By the way the icons are outside the headermenu that's closed off above the iconsbut, and as it's usually shunted out to the right there should be room for the icons to sit above it. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS driving me mad!
ResponsesInList.Text: doh! thats what happens when i try to do three things at the same time! How you cope with all the different theme fixes and the forum all going at once, I'll never know! Wood, trees and forests all spring to mind when looking at so much code the last day or two - how did I miss the blindingly obvious !!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS driving me mad!
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, You need to use #header-home NOT #header so your code would be like so... #header-home div.icons { width: 300px; height: 26px; position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 20px; z-index: 20; text-align: right; } #header-home div.icons img { margin-left: 5px; } The fact you have position: absolute you should be able to move the div about the header to position where you want it to land. Not so sure about the z-index unless one is assigned to #header-home already will that one work? Anyway...let me know how you get on. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Logo problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Probably it is easiest to make changes to your header.html file in an html editor program like Front Page or Dreamweaver.  Then, when you add an image as background of a cell in a table (like the tables in the example html file I posted above), you will be adding html code that looks like this:  background="/theme/the name of your theme folder/yourlogo.jpg" Then you would put your logo image in your theme folder.

ResponsesInList.Title: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text:
Howdy. I am going to target this question at Mary, but if anyone else knows the answer please feel free to chime in. I have created a theme that has 5 new regions added to them. My probelm is the Calendar page. When viewing the calendar it is saying the region is not defined. What layout is used for the calendar? I have a 'general' layout but nowhere in config.php have I yet assigned a layout to be used by the calendar page specifically. I do not even know if you can. My custom regions work on all other pages as I have defined them i.e. 
```text
'base' => array(
        'file' => 'general.php',
        'regions' => array('side-pre', 'side-post','search'),
        'defaultregion' => 'side-post',
    ),
```
 Thoughts?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text: In calendar/view.php moodle has $PAGE->set_pagelayout('standard'); so your theme config.php should probably have lines 'standard' => array( 'file' => 'general.php', 'regions' => array('side-pre', 'side-post'), 'defaultregion' => 'side-post', ), (if it is not using parent theme layouts) Base theme config.php should have all core layouts in $THEME->layouts = array()

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text: Of all the ones to miss I had not specified 'standard'. I had howeverdone a good 8 others. You my kind sir are a LEGEND! ;) Julian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Julian, I'm not sure the region you are talking about is actually to do with the Calendar at this stage, it is I suspect more to do with the fact you have not declared the 5 new regions in your layouts (general.php and frontpage.php) Also you need to say where ALL the 'new' regions are going to be employed in the different Theme layouts in your theme's config.php, much the same way 'side-pre' and 'side-post' are. So you could have the following for the 'fronfpage' layout...like so 'frontpage' => array( 'file' => 'frontpage.php', 'regions' => array('side-pre', 'side-post, 'topside-pre', 'topside-post', 'footer-pre', 'footer-mid', 'footer-post') , 'defaultregion' => 'topside-post', 'options' => array('langmenu'=>true), ), These 5 new regions would need declaring in frontpage.php in the head section which would look something like this... $hastopsidepre = $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('topside-pre', $OUTPUT); $hastopsidepost = $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('topside-post', $OUTPUT); $hasfooterpre = $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('footer-pre', $OUTPUT); $hasfootermid = $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('footer-pre', $OUTPUT); $hastfooterpost = $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('footer-post', $OUTPUT); Then in each of the regions you have created you must state what happens IF these regions are going to appear with something like this... <?php { if ($hastopsidepre) echo $OUTPUT->blocks_for_region('topside-pre'); } ?> Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mary, The issue here was that I was not sure what layout was being used by calendar pages. Turns out it is the 'standard' laout. Once I added this to my config with definitions for my additional regions it all now works fine. Might be nice for Calendar to have its own layout moving forward. Julian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Tricky question re Layouts (Calendar)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Julian, That's OK...I was just using an example for where I am at the moment with my theme. Such a lot to learn! I look forward to seeing your new theme. Be sure to add it to the NEW Plugin Database for Themes Also, when you come to add this theme, have a few images to add too as well as all the requred documentation! LOL Regards Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Theming Challenges
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle presents a lot of flexibility concerning themes. However, through 1.8.2 at least, it has a couple issues that making theming difficult, at least for me. Use of BR Tag - While great for a line break without the margin/padding settings of the P tag, it seems to get used in Moodle a lot as a spacer. If indeed we wish to use a tag for spacing, wouldn't something like <DIV class="spacer" id="spacer-#"> work better because we could effect individual instances of the spacer through the id (something already done with other elements) or effect all .spacer elements on a page through > .spacer? Or couldn't we just use the margin/padding settings instead for the same effect? Sometimes I find I have to target a specific BR and display:none it. Use of TABLES - From 1.7 to 1.8, I noticed the disappearance of a bunch of tables; however, the conversion seems only part way. The main layout still has three columns. The course formats still have tables. Many modules like the forum still have tables. If they used a DIV/LI style layout, manipulating positions through CSS would be far easier. Changing the hardcoding isn't an option for the development environment I am working in, so wondering what sort of workarounds other themers use?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theming Challenges
ResponsesInList.Text: This is gradually being improved. For example, I recently took a lot of s out of the quiz attempt and review pages. But it is also something that most people don't have a lot of time to work on. Bug fixes and new features tend to take priority. If you want to help, you can identify specific problem pieces of HTML, and ideally, suggest what HTML should be used instead. If possible, file these in the tracker, and attach the fix as a patch. Urs Hunkler is probably the core developer who does most to improve themability, and I would not be suprised if he posts to this thread in due course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theming Challenges
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm keeping a list of little issues I've found and I'll post them into JIRA under a low priority.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Robert, 1. If you are making any changes to your theme it is a good idea to turn on Theme Designer Mode as Moodle caches all css (and many other things) which prevents changes from showing correctly - with Theme Designer Mode enabled, caching is prevented and your changes will show up as you make them 2. The Themes folder is not available as part of filepicker as it is outside the moodledata folder. you will need access to the files on your server , probably through ftp or through your webhost 's control panel to upload any themes. 3. This is part of moodle's own language files and not part of the theme - I believe it can be edited through Site Admin->Language->Language customisation, although i haven't actually done this myself, so someone with more knowledge in this particular area may be able to help you more. HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Robert, 1. Like Richard says enabeling Theme Designer Mode in Site-Administration > Appearance > Themes > Theme Settings(2nd from top of page) 2. Depending on who owns the site, you will need to upload the theme in the same way Moodle was uploaded. If Moodle was installed using a software installer, then you will most probably be able to upload the theme to the theme folder of your Moodle site using File Manger which you will find in your Control Panel on your site. 3. To change the message in Autentication Login page go to Settings > Site-Administration  > Plugins > Authentication and you will see various sections listed all to do with the settings for Authenticated Login. You will need to read all of them to decide which options you need or don't need. I think from memory the message is in the section E-Mail Authentication. HTH Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello again Robert, I have just been testing None-Zero and it looks like there is a BUG with this theme. Indeed I am surprised no one has found it. The reason the Customised CSS does not work is the fact is there is no provision set in the CSS file for Custom CSS... However if you add the following to the end on core.css file for the theme, save and refresh your theme, the changes should take effect. /** Custom CSS **/ setting:customcss I'm going to commit this to Moodle Tracker and get it fixed as this is a CORE theme. Sorry for the inconvenience. Mary MDL-26700

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Not display the home page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Have you modified just the image (using photoshop/GIMP etc.) and saved it in the same location and with the same name? Or have you altered any of the code to point to your new image? Coming up with a blank screen usually means there is an error in the page code. Try going back to a different theme (if you had enable themes on url set then add ?theme=standard to your page url - if not you may have to cut the 'mytheme' folder out of the themes folder: replace 'mytheme' with whatever theme you are using) and turn on debugging, then go back to your edited theme. Site Administration->Development->Debugging that should help you find the error. HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Dr Dey, Have you turned on theme designer mode? In Moodle2 css (and many other things) are cached, in order to see the changes you make to the css files you should either turn on theme designer mode (Site Administration-> Appearance-> Themes-> Theme Settings) or you will need to purge the cahce each time (Site Administration-> Development-> Purge All Caches) HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 2.0 Theme Questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Good day, Dr. Day: I'm sorry I got to this a little late, so apologies for that. However, I don't have much to add to what Richard has said, other than Read the Moodle Docs . There are a number of 'Help' files available. The most important is Development: Themes 2.0 and if you take a look at that page there is a set of tutorials at the foot of it which you will find invaluable when learning to customise Moodle 2 themes. Firebug too is worth learning about if you don't already use this. A point to remember, is that it is generally frowned upon to customise a CORE theme like 'Brick' as this theme, like all core themes, are updated during Moodle 2 updates, and so any changes you make to this theme will be lost. The best thing to do in this case is to 'clone' that theme. You can read how to do this in Development: Themes 2.0 how to clone a Moodle 2.0 theme HTH Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle - Creating Themes / Theme Simple Study
ResponsesInList.Text:
I presume your css file is called base.css? Personally, I would recommend adding a parent theme (probably base) 
```text
$THEME
->
parents 
=
 array
('base');
```
 because at the moment, with no parent theme, you have none of the layout files declared other than the base one, and if as you say your css file is empty, then you have no css to fall back to either. If you declare a parent theme, then your theme can fall back to the layout files used in the parent, but without any parent, I don't think it will work as there are no layout files declared anywhere (@Mary or @Gareth - would Moodle fall back to the base layout for other page layouts if none are declared ie there is no parent, even base/bootstrapbase? I don't think it would, but haven't specifically tested that. EDIT : just tried in a Moodle3 site by removing the layout files from bootstrapbase config.php and selecting that as the theme - error messages, but the page is there so must be picking up the base layout, I guess). Hmmm, OK. As well as the Main Content token changing that Mary has already mentioned, from somewhere around Moodle 2.2 or 2.3 a version.php became a required file in the setup of your theme and your theme will not install without it. If you are using such an old version of Moodle as 2.0 or 2.1, please see https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Creating_a_theme for instructions If you are using a newer version (bearing in mind that Moodle is now at v.3 and even 2.7LTS is only security fixes now), then please see https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Clean_theme , or the readme file in the Clean theme itself. TBH if you are using something as old as 2.0 or 2.1 then I would ask the question 'why?' If the purpose of your theme is for testing and studying, surely you should be looking at an upto date version of Moodle and how themes work in that. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle - Creating Themes / Theme Simple Study
ResponsesInList.Text: Following on from my last comment... I assume you are using Moodle 2.1 or older as the layout main content TOKEN changed in Moodle 2.2 From this... https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_21_STABLE/theme/base/layout/frontpage.php#L56 to this... https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_22_STABLE/theme/base/layout/frontpage.php#L56

ResponsesInList.Title: Pioneer Theme : Is there a BUG in Icon nav URL markup?
ResponsesInList.Text:
In trying to solve a problem with the Lang menu in Pioneer I think I have came across a 'bug' in the icon navigation in the top menu bar url settings. If you do not customise these icons urls, in the Pioneer settings page immediately after installing the theme, then the default URLs will not work if your moodle site url is written something like this in the config.php: 
```text
$CFG->
wwwroot
   = 'http://localhost/moodle';
```
 Has anyone else found this to be true? Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer Theme : Is there a BUG in Icon nav URL markup?
ResponsesInList.Text: Mary, The icon navigation uses defaults when installed which are based on Moodle being in the root folder to build the 4 icons.  If you installed it in a subdirectory you should edit the Icon Navigation URL 's in the theme settings page for them. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer Theme : Is there a BUG in Icon nav URL markup?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chris, That is not necessarily so as you can add this in the PHP markup in the layout/includes/iconnav.php file like so... ```text theme->settings->nav4icon) { ?> ``` Where new moodle_url = $CFG->wwwroot This is how I was taught to do this. Also some words 'language strings' you add in the settings page should technically be a string so that it can get translated. For example: 'Home' or 'Calendar' should be get_string('home', 'moodle') or get_string('calendar', 'calendar') most words of this nature are already translated so knowing this its easy to add. On the other hand the 'fa' font icon names are different as these are, in effect' code names and NOT strings. I'm surprised no one pulled you up on that when the theme was originally reviewed. Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer Theme : Is there a BUG in Icon nav URL markup?
ResponsesInList.Text: All my themes use this so I will need to take a look.  I am first going to update Fordson then Pioneer.  Thanks for helping. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: No themes to select
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to create a custom theme and something has barfed my moodle install. I renamed the folder because screens were going blank -- to make it default to standard. That worked. When I now go to choose a theme, I get nothing but a white page with nothing on it. HELP!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No themes to select
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The theme you are trying to create is, most likly, causing the problem. The best thing to do is remove it from your server . You can download it to your desktop, then delete it off your server. Next you need to look at ever file inside that theme to see that the theme name coresponds with the name of the theme on the folder it is in. Then you need to assess each directory inside the theme to see if you have all the required parts all named and referenced back to the config.php, like the name of the CSS files the LAYOUT files frontpage.php & general.php. Read the documents found in the header of the Themems' Forum. Odds on you have an error of two, which is sufficient to stop it working. Removing the file will default to standard theme, providing you have not changed standard theme too. HTH Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No themes to select
ResponsesInList.Text: I removed them and can now see the other themes. Excellent! Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Customize the themes? Can any one help please?
ResponsesInList.Text: As a newbie myself I've been directed to the documentation. Follow this link: Themes It will give you the basics. After that you will need to start learning some php and html. One thing that I will say is that you should get notepad++, assuming that you are on a windows box, to edit the .php files. Basically, your best bet would be to start with a theme that is already available and try to modify it. I'm starting with the header.html file myself. I'm trying to add custom logos. For your questions however you would need to create cascading style sheets. This can be done in notepad++ as well. If you try to use word it won't work. Word just adds junk and messes up the code. If you use notepad it is hard to see the logical structures in the code. ++ made things a lot easier for me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme - standardise height of marketing spots
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Stephen, That issue was many moons ago and the code has since changed. There is not yet any automatic way of setting the height of the marketing spots to be all the same height. Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: The removal of the course category icon navigation in 1.5.3 has prompted some users to ask why the change? They really liked the grid layout of categories. I understand the reason for removing them but is there a way to use a grid layout for the categories instead of the standard accordion list?  The standard category list layout just looks completely out of place compared to the previous icon category layout. Thanks again for this great theme. Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: After feedback from our users we saw that when clicking to find courses they would get lost and spend lots of time going back and forth.  We have over 1500 courses in many categories and if the user got buried in a category it was harder using icons than the current method to get back out and look elsewhere. If there is enough interest I can take a look at making the icon an option to turn on and off.  Because we use Fordson for our production site we make changes based on what our users want and I don't necessarily think of others.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Seeing that others may have liked the icons I am making a setting that will allow the user to choose which layout they prefer.  Will be published later today as a fix.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris, Thank you - that would be great. I must say you offer amazing support for your theme. Keep on rockin! Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Version 1.5.4 is published here and on github.  It adds a new toggle which will allow you to enable the category icons again. Since the theme is so new I didn't know people would be attached to certain elements of the design. If you have usability suggestions please post them. We have one other major feature we are working on in which we want to integrate a grading panel which will show teachers items that need grading.  Much like the teacher and student dashboards, this will slide down and present items much like some of the "Marking Blocks" do.  With integration in the theme you can free up space for learning content and avoid adding a block that eat's up space.  Our teachers have been asking for a way to quickly see what things need grading.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Fordson v1.5.3 - removal of icon categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Very early on we had used an image but it was confusing because the categories had images and then the courses used images. People didn't know if they were clicking on a category or course. That's when we decided to drop images for categories and just use icons to distinguish them from courses. José Miguel Dager Montoya is a moodle user who originally helped with icons and images for courses and course categories.  You can try contacting him to see if he continued to develop the image aspect of categories for Fordson.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot Get to Forums Preferences
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Annie, That's not the theme name, that's just the setting in either the course settings page or a user profile when the ability to override the site theme is enabled at one of those levels. ResponsesInList.Title: styles_color.css impacting themes and unread post highlighting
ResponsesInList.Text: Here is the condensed version: If you want unread post highlighting to work then you need to ensure you have the ".unread" class specified. I just posted over on tracker http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-18971 I have cross-posted this to the Forum Module forum as well. The styles_color. css includes the ".unread" class in the core section. Unfortunately, a number of the Moodle supplied themes do not include the ".unread" class. This results in unread posts failing to be highlighted in various themes that do not include the styles_color.css or a specific ".unread" class (examples include formal_white, chameleon, etc.). The forum section of styles_color.css has a number of combined classes where the first class is never defined. Example: .forumthread .unread {

ResponsesInList.Title: Why are forms made so narrow in base theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not a graphic designer, so feel free to revert these changes if they destroy your beautiful design, but I think that the width:60% and margin-right:16%; are a waste of space, so I tool them out. Index: theme/base/style/core. css =================================================================== RCS file: /cvsroot/moodle/moodle/theme/base/style/core.css,v retrieving revision 1.56 diff -u -r1.56 core.css --- theme/base/style/core.css 4 Aug 2010 09:13:27 -0000 1.56 +++ theme/base/style/core.css 4 Aug 2010 18:32:32 -0000 @@ -177,7 +177,7 @@ .mform .fitem {width:100%;overflow:hidden;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:1px;clear:right;} .mform .fitem .fitemtitle {width:15%;text-align:right;float:left;} .mform .fitem .fitemtitle div {display: inline;}

ResponsesInList.Title: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys. I hope you can help me with this question. How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud? Apparently I don't have ftp user. Best regards.
role: Picture of Juan Andrés García Morales

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't.  A theme is a plugin.  As the FAQ - https://moodle.com/cloud/faq/ - states under 'Does MoodleCloud allow plugins?' -> 'No. Our free MoodleCloud sites are made dead-simple with the use of the standard Moodle theme, More.'.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: https://moodle.com/cloud/ To keep things manageable our sites do have some limits: 50 users maximum. 200Mb disk space Core themes and plugins only One site per phone number

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: You can pick MORE, and then customize it.  Site Admin | Appearance | Themes | MORE. I use MORE on my small site, and I am very please with it.  However, I have customized it with CSS code.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Have any of you tried it out?  You cannot pick Clean or More you can only customise the main theme which is called 'moodlecloud' and has adverts. https://bylazydaisy.moodlecloud.com I queried it in a tracker. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to implement a theme if I have my Moodle site hosted on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes - what Mary says. You can only customise the moodlecloud theme (which is a customised More theme anyway) The reason for this is that it has the adverts on it which are necessary to fund the free site. I agree it should be clearer in the admin section that you can't edit the other ones; the issue has been raised.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Trying to create Moodle Button in Activity modules?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fabio, When you added it to view.php I guess this is in Moodle system files? ResponsesInList.Title: Overriding a renderer with namespace
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear All, I am not able to override the renderer (based on Boost, Moodle 3.2) in my own theme . I read all the documentation and forum posts I could find, my problem is identical to this: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=324201 This was working in the past, for example: require_once($CFG-> dirroot .'/mod/quiz/renderer.php'); class theme_mytheme_mod_quiz_renderer extends mod_quiz_renderer { ..... } My new  attempt with namespace: namespace theme_mytheme\output; defined('MOODLE_INTERNAL') || die; require_once($CFG->dirroot.'/mod/quiz/renderer.php'); class mod_quiz_renderer extends \mod\quiz\renderer { ........ I get the "class not found" message, I tried at least 20 different combinations I could think of, but with no success. Could someone let me know how to accomplish the same thing now? Thanks in advance! Gabor

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Overriding a renderer with namespace
ResponsesInList.Text: This file has the best examples of all the possible valid places to put a renderer. https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/tests/outputfactories_test.php Your class name looks fine - and I'm assuming you put that in the file: theme/mytheme/classes/output/mod_quiz_renderer.php Did you clear caches? The mappings of classname to filename are cached so you always need to purge caches when adding a new auto-loaded class to Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Overriding a renderer with namespace
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much, Damyon! Your post helped me find the right path, I had problems with cache and with the filename... Now I get the method, and it works.

Thanks in advance!

ResponsesInList.Title: Insert a large logo ingenious theme
ResponsesInList.Text: I managed to insert a logo into the ingenious theme, but the dimensions are too small (100px) when I try to insert a larger logo, even by a couple more pixels- it corrupts the page and changes the layout of the whole page. Is there a way around this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Insert a large logo ingenious theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Best way to get round this problem would be to set the width of .headermain in the styles. css . In which case you will need to add this code to the styles.css. h1.headermain { margin: 0; padding: 0; width: 400px; height: 100px } You can set this to the width/height of the proposed Logo image you want to add, you can also change the margin/padding to suit your page layout. Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi! I want to add media attributes in the CSS files that I include through theme config.php so that I can specify different breakpoints with the files to serve CSS property for a specific case like the following: 
```text
<link rel="stylesheet" media="(min-device-width: 768px) and (max-device-width: 991px)" href="medium.css" />
```
 Thanks, Rajnish

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't, you'll break the way Moodle works.  Instead, put the media queries in the CSS itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Basically I want to optimize my pages. Let say I have a banner.png which size is 300KB and dimension is 1200x500px, here I want to serve banner_small.png with dimension 767x200 px (or what ever the aspect ration of the 1200x500 if I resized its with by 767px) for smartphones which size would be defiantly less than the larger one If I will use media queries in the css file itself, both image will be called, although the "banner_small.png"  will appear on the smartphone. Hope you understand my query! Best, Rajnish

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Read: http://www.w3schools.com/css/css_rwd_images.asp https://css-tricks.com/responsive-images-youre-just-changing-resolutions-use-srcset/ http://caniuse.com/#search=srcset And if you use media queries in the CSS, then 'no', both images will not be served if you write it properly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes you are right "if you use media queries in the CSS , then 'no', both images will not be served if you write it properly".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to add media attributes while adding a CSS file in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: "And if you use media queries in the CSS , then 'no', both images will not be served if you write it properly." Sort of, both images won't be displayed but both images will be downloaded , defeating the purpose of optimising for the mobile. If you want to avoid the browser downloading all of the versions, don't use CSS media queries, use HTML5's srcset or CSS's newer image-set . This page explains them well: https://css-tricks.com/responsive-images-css/

ResponsesInList.Title: Boost Child Theme custom template
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys! Im working in a child theme and need extend the columns2.mustache file to add some code. How I load my templates folder to override the original file? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost Child Theme custom template
ResponsesInList.Text: The best thing to do is find and read the Moodle Development Docs about the Mustache templates .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost Child Theme custom template
ResponsesInList.Text:
Copy the required template into your child theme templates folder (and edit it) and call it from the layout file e.g. https://github.com/roelmann/moodle-theme_waxed/blob/master/layout/columns2.php#L55 
```text
echo $OUTPUT->render_from_template('
theme_waxed
/columns2
', $templatecontext);
```
 The same line in Boost would be 
```text
echo $OUTPUT->render_from_template('
theme_boost/columns2
', $templatecontext);
```
 while some of the templates I use in Waxed are the original Boost ones and so are called as theme_boost/templatename from within the waxed layout or templte files as appropriate. As well as the docs Mary has linked to, take a look at Waxed or Fordson for some practical examples.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost Child Theme custom template
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for help! Works fine!

ResponsesInList.Title: Dynamic web pages
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not sure if it comes under the same category but here is something I am looking to achieve. With a static width size for your .surround class when a browser is minimised it either fits perfectly with the surround or it cover the left and right border of the surround area. I have seen some webpages where when you reduce the minimise the size of the browser the middle portion (.surround) gets reduced as well hence fitting perfectly within the minimised page. Occasionally I need to accomodate this for the front page and word document pages that our users open from any other page. I hope its clear what I am trying to achieve please let me know if you would like more explanation. Can anyone help?? Vijay

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dynamic web pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi vijay, Whenever I design a theme I try to make it fluid, in that it will resize to any browser setting. The way this is achieved is using a simple layout, as found in  Moodle 1.9 Standard theme, or the Base theme in Moodle 2.0, and make canges to the CSS for the #page element, like so... #page { width: 95%; margin: 0 auto; padding: 0;} This simple bit of code sets the parameter for the outer shell of the theme. Whatever happens inside this #page structure, providing all width values of all elements are in percentages, and that padding is accounted for in these final width setting, as padding ADDS to the width, then all will work nicely. Moodle 2.0 is a little more tricky as you have to make absolutely sure the side-pre-only and side-post-only and content only settings in the CSS are exactly right for your theme. Getting this wrong spells catastrophy for your theme, because this is what the layout for the theme hinges on. Hope this is useful to you...indeed I might have even got the your question wrong!In which case this is perhaps not what you need! LOL Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dynamic web pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vijay, The problem with both the header and the footer is that there is a mismatch of div tags, more opening than closing in the header. The footer has duplicated HTML for the table structure. Also the css for the footer has been commented out, not sure why. I am assuming you know how to fix these things. To make the whole site more flexible, all you need to do is change all the fixed width values to 100% but make .surround 95% like the examples I uploaded here. Let me know how you get on. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dynamic web pages
ResponsesInList.Text: I've had another look at the two files, it seems the way they have structure is that opening tags in the header are closed in the footer with the last div tag as content class which is open in the header.html and closed in the footer.html. Quite interesting, never seen that method of applying tags in different files. So when the header ends it open up the content and closes with the footer. All the div are in the right numbers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Dynamic web pages
ResponsesInList.Text: But the div tags in the header should all close in the header. If you look in Standard theme's header.html you will see that the divs are opened and closed using php... <?php print_container_start(true, '', 'header-home'); ?> <?php print_container_end(); ?> Notice where they are opened and where they are closed. There is no reason your theme should be different. I don't think this it is design feature but rather someone not understading what they are doing. In fact the header and footer do't really need to be altered that much, but some designers like to be creative and start to dismantle something which works efficiently and ends up with a theme which people ask to make it do something it was not designed to do. Standard theme on it's own works beautifully, and with the correct styling can look as you want it to. Did you try changing the .surround width to 95% and #page to 100% and margins to 0 auto, plus change all the fixed width settings? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some questions about adapting Adaptable 1.7
ResponsesInList.Text: I will try to answer your questions: I added the Progress Completion block, but I'd like it to sit in the middle, stretched across the screen when a student is viewing course activities /resources. I made a row to hold a single block, but I can't drag the Progress block into it. I understand you are talking about the course page. In that case just add the block in the top region and add the block there. See the demo site: https://adaptable.ws/demo/course/view.php?id=5 (login as student or teacher) Is it possible to hide the right-side blocks and set the site to display in full screen, and hide the Show Blocks/Standard View options? No. This is always a user setting. But you can change the default setting. Just search viewselect in the Administration block. A trick could be to hide the button from users once set viewselect to full screen. Is there a way to send students directly to the first uncompleted activity when they open a course, instead of showing the activities list? This is a course format question and not related to the theme. Try to find one that meet your requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: #1 Reason why fixed-width Moodle themes are difficult to achieve ...
ResponsesInList.Text:
Popups. Consider the CSS to fix all (known) popup windows: 
```text
#message-index #footer,



#message-discussion #footer,



#message-history #footer,



#mod-glossary-showentry #footer,



#mod-glossary-showentry #header,



#mod-glossary-showentry .navbar,



#help #footer {



  display:none;



}
```
 You're welcome, by the way! And, I promise that I have missed one or two items that need individual attention. Would it be possible to add a single class that appears in all popups so that this can be styled all at once? I don't know anything about the programming side, so I'm really asking.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm looking for some ideas here before I try to reinvent the wheel. I've been thinking about tailoring the look of courses according to the subject - a sort of colour-coding would be a start. I know it's possible to allow courses to set their own themes, but that's probably more than I want.  As an example, if I had a site with courses for general English, technical English and business English (or maybe different levels using the snooker ball colours), I wouldn't want to change the theme completely for each category, but I might want to change the colour scheme while keeping the corporate look.  I guess this would be possible if I duplicated themes and then gave them different names.  That way changes could be made while keeping the overall look the same. So my question is this...  Is this feasible, or is there more involved to duplicating the theme than just changing the name.  Following on from that, am I going to have problems when the original theme gets updated? Am I creating an over-complicated workflow here or is there an easier way? Any thoughts or suggestions would be appreciated. all the best Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: thinking about using different themes on one site
ResponsesInList.Text: There is a simpler way if you dont need the separate departments to be able to apply the settings and you can have the colour scheme controlled centrally. In the body classes every course and category applies a course-x and category-x body class. You can use that to target the css for the colour scheme in the customcss setting which would then allow the settings to be used for the main site, and only the course/category specific overrides to be applied over that just as required without needing to have multiple child themes. It also ensures the overall corporate look and feel is not changed by someone with their own theme settings. Of course that alters if you do need each area to make use of the individual settings from the theme, in which case you are probably into cloning your theme and then managing the child or clone as an ongoing task and you can find more information about that in the readme of the Clean file (the advice there applies to the vast majority of current themes).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: thinking about using different themes on one site
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, CSS is static, PHP is not.  Therefore it is quick and easy to add CSS to address an issue.  However it is not that robust against the dynamic changes of course / category ids etc.  Code can be dynamic, reactive and cope with change, but it takes longer and is harder to create.  Therefore you choose the solution that bests suits your situation and need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: thinking about using different themes on one site
ResponsesInList.Text: I do this on my site, and it's not hard or difficult to maintain. First, you select a parent theme for your whole site. Then you create a child theme for each course based on your parent theme. You only need to include a few files in each child theme, one of which is a CSS style sheet. Each child theme's style sheet only needs to include the CSS unique to that course. It gets the rest of the CSS from the parent theme. Do a search for how to create child themes. There's documentation about which files to include in the child theme and how to define its parent.

ResponsesInList.Title: Have a problem installing a new theme
ResponsesInList.Text: I need help on how to install a new theme. Can anyone help me

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Have a problem installing a new theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Most themes simply need to be uploaded to the theme folder on your Moodle installation. However, you should read any accompanying text included in the theme you are uploading, usually available as a "readme.txt" file. Once the theme is uploaded (you can use an FTP client to do this, such as FileZilla) you should see it in the available themes (Site Administration>Appearance>Themes>Theme Selector) or simply type in your domain name/theme and you'll get to this location. Select the Choose button for the theme you want and it should be installed across your site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Multi-language Support for Slider in Academi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi-language Support for Slider in Academi
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I don't know, you would be better contacting the theme designer HERE. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi-language Support for Slider in Academi
ResponsesInList.Text: In academi, the slider caption is set as PARAM_TEXT, so I don't think it will accept the multilang filter, but the main body of the slide description is an html editor, so if you install other language packs and apply the multilang filter (or one of the more advanced options in the plugins database - search for multang2) then it should work there. You could try enabling the filter for headings and see if that applies to the caption as a text only area, but I don't think it will. The option then is to leave the caption blank and use the html editor to style part of the slide description as a header, applying the multilang filter as required. (There are good instructions on using it with the multilang2 filter and an accompnaying atto tool to use in the editor.) R
