ResponsesInList.Title: Different themes for different users
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi This is what I want to do... I have Moodle set up with a number of courses; different organisations all log into the same Moodle to access the same courses. If a learner from Organisation 1 logs in, they see a "branded" screen for their organisation; if a learner from Organisation 2 logs in, they see a "branded" screen for their organisation, and so on... I know you can assign themes to a course and a users can choose a them themselves, but is it possible to maybe have themes linked to Groups or Cohorts? If so, all learners in Organisation 1 can go into one group/cohort with their own theme and so on for each organisation. Any help or advise would be very much appreciated. Nick

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Different themes for different users
ResponsesInList.Text: You can do this with categories.  You can brand each category seperately and also assign people in roles specific to that category.  Works pretty well for set ups like yours.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Different themes for different users
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your reply. So would the category be "themed" and contain the courses? Ideally I need everyone to access the same set of courses, but for each user to see a different theme based on what organisation they work for? Will that work?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Different themes for different users
ResponsesInList.Text: I dont believe there is yet a cohort or group option for applying themes, and if you want the users to access teh same courses, then Emma's categories solution probably isn't right for you either - you could possibly duplicate the courses into different categories, but that is porbably not ideal from a tutor/manager/admin point of view and also means that the 'non-course' parts of the site, such as their profile are not themed. Depending on the scale of changes you want to make, it would be possible to use a conditional statement based on the 'Institution' field in a user profile (ie the company they work for). This could then add a class to the body and you could use that to alter the css for branding as required. I wouldn't recommend that for much beyond the logo and a few headline colour changes though, but that may be sufficient for you to provide the distinguishing between the client companies.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Different themes for different users
ResponsesInList.Text: Nick, The only way to achieve user-based themes in the same course is to enable user themes, see https://docs.moodle.org/28/en/Theme_settings#Allow_user_themes You would then set the theme in the user's profile record.  Emma's suggestion for category themes is the usual way this is done.  But if you want all users in the same course, you have to go the user theme route. Floyd

As the issue seems a bit beyond my depth, the best solution I've come up with so far has been to shorten the transition time as much as possible so that the issue is less noticeable (I tried setting it to 0s but then the menu doesn't close once opened)... div.nav-collapse.pull-left.collapse { transition: height 0.01s ease; } This doesn't really solve the issue completely so I'm hoping a cleaner fix will present itself. Any thoughts or advice would be much appreciated. JP

ResponsesInList.Title: Theme Install From Within Moodle (like wordpress)
ResponsesInList.Text: I have recently hacked away at my site's theme and am happy with the results ( http://moodle.carmelunified.org ) and then I went over to my wordpress run blog and decided to update its theme. I really like how in wordpress I can search for themes (and all plugins) within the admin panel and then install them (no download / upload /unzip required). This got me thinking about 2 things: 1. Could Moodle allow installing themes and other plugins direct from the moodle backend? This might allow people to update their moodle more effectively. 2. Is there any way we could create a plugin that would take a wordpress or joomla) theme and make it style a typical moodle site?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme Install From Within Moodle (like wordpress)
ResponsesInList.Text: 1. The issue with this is security. The thing a hacker would really like to do is to get whatever PHP code they like executed by your server . If they can do that, you are totally screwed. So, the thought of changing Moodle, so that it will automatically download code from somewhere on the internet, and then execute it as part of Moodle, fills people who care about security with horror. There is a lot to be said with the current system where you have to download the code manually, check it over, then upload it to your server yourself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme Install From Within Moodle (like wordpress)
ResponsesInList.Text: I see what you mean re: security. I don't mind the current system (its pretty darn easy), I just encountered the different approach with Wordpress and was curious. Thanks for taking the time to respond. I look forward to learning themes in Moodle 2.0!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: track all.css in essential theme
ResponsesInList.Text: all.css is generated and cached from the separate css sources. If you turn on Theme Designer Mode you will see where the individual css comes from (which file) and be able to edit it there. However, you also need to be aware that much of the css in essential is actually generated from its LESS files and should be edited (and re-processed) there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme Selection on Homepage
ResponsesInList.Text: You see an example of session themes (by Urs Hunkler) here http://moodle.unodo.de/?&theme=orangewhite http://moodle.unodo.de/?&theme=elearningkontor_tabs http://moodle.unodo.de/?&theme=standardwhite You only need to make a ThemeSwitcher (block there) or drop down menu with those selected links. To get all theme names from theme folder needs a little php or javascript but it is certainly possible. If I have some extra time during weekend I could try to write that script to theme header.html The basic idea is that when user selects a theme from switcher (or button) it is saved to session / cookie. I have used buttons like in Joomla templates to change theme or font size. They use a small javascript but idea is the same as Urs is using. In a standard Moodle installation, session themes are not active. To activate them the administrator must add the parameter `$CFG->allowthemechangeonurl = true;` to the Moodle config.php file in the Moodle base directory. If you use that other method, javascript is included to theme folder itself and there is no need to change config.php.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme Selection on Homepage
ResponsesInList.Text: Wow!! Thanks. So easy! I have inserted a link to two of our themes within the Main Menu Sideblock and works the way we want it. Please do not work over your hard earned weekend off, the kind help you have gave was sufficient. Many thanks, and have a good week end. Ali.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme Selection on Homepage
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ali, I made one version of a script (php+javascript) that reads all theme names from theme folder and makes a drop down list with automatic hyperlinks. ResponsesInList.Title: Issues with Adaptable Naviagation
ResponsesInList.Text: Using a fresh installation of Moodle 3.5 and Adaptable 1.7 (both taken directly from moodle.org on July 7) and no other plugins I can confirm the following bugs in the navigation: 2nd level drop-down menus do not work (they do work on mobile devices, however) On sites with several menu items which end up wrapping onto more than one line, if two top-level menu items in different line are above and below each other, and if each has a first level sub list, then if you open the higher one and move your mouse down along the sub menu, as you pass the lower menu item, the lower submenu opens preventing you from being able to click on the lower items in the first list. That last point is a bit confusing so here is a quick video to demonstrate.  In the video, you can see that Menu Item 1 is above Menu Item 27.  When I hover above Menu Item 1, it exposes Menu Item 2 through Menu Item 5 in its drop-down menu.  As I move my mouse down the menu, when I get to around Menu Item 3, the submenu for Menu Item 27 appears instead. I reported this on bitbucket: https://bitbucket.org/covuni/moodle-theme_adaptable/issues/923/navigation-bar-sub-menus

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Compatibility with IE8
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alex, The code given in the link can be added as a meta tag in the header.html of the theme you are using. Meta tags go in the <head> part of the header.html file. It is best to use a Text Editor like Notepad to do this. However, I would be more inclined to try and fix the problem you are having with this theme in IE8 rather than try to force compatibility mode which may not even work in this case.  Most themes that Shaun has created work OK in IE8, so I don't see this theme being any different. ResponsesInList.Title: Page layout Files in Theme - Moodle 2.9.3
ResponsesInList.Text: I've adjusted some of my page layouts with a variety of success but the one I want to adjust is for the display of the courses. Many Thanks Dave Emsley

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Page layout Files in Theme - Moodle 2.9.3
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dave, The layout is not something you copy, it is more to do with which layout page you decide to use. If you look at Bootstrapbase theme the layout is defined as "columns3.php" see here... https://github.com/lazydaisy/moodle/blob/master/theme/bootstrapbase/config.php#L63-L67 So all you need to do is make sure your theme has that list of layouts so that you can choose which of your theme layouts to use when in a "course category" cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Page layout Files in Theme - Moodle 2.9.3
ResponsesInList.Text: Many, many thanks. Mary.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Page layout Files in Theme - Moodle 2.9.3
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, You also need to make sure you define the regions for the particular layouts, paying particular notice to the defined states these layouts are given by default. Also if you enable 'Allow page info' when in Debugging mode you can see what each page uses as a layout. Some, like the calendar, use Standard layout that has three columns, but it becomes clear that that layout is wrong for the calendar, so in cases like that you could if you wanted, make it a two column page. Hope that helps? Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm using formal_white that came with 2.1. All I want to do is change the default Moodle logo to my own -- no other changes. That logo is in the theme folder for formal_white in the \pix directory (logo.png and logo_small.png). I changed the names of both so I didn't lose them, and created my logos with the same names (and sizes) and moved them into the same folder. But the default logo still displays. So I read Themes 2.0 How to use images within your theme and tried the code instructions there. Still no luck. I know there are significant changes in themes in the 2.x releases, but what else do I need to do?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Nancy, Have you purged all caches, or do you have Theme designer mode turned on? Settings->Site Administration->Development->Purge all caches or Settings->Site Administration->Appearance->Themes->Theme Settings If, as you say, you only want to make the one change then I would suggest just using the purge caches, but if you are planning on making more changes then the theme designer mode enables yo to see the changes you make. HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Oh, dear... I purged the caches, shut down the system (I'm running a stand-alone test machine), and restarted it. The logo on the login page changed, but the next screen comes up totally blank -- so I can't see or do anything! What happened?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you made any other changes to the theme at all? Simply changing the logo and restarting/purging should not cause this problem - it is more often caused by an error/typo in the php of the layout file in my experience. If you have made any changes you should go back and check those changes as a simple missed semi-colon can cause problems in the php. If you have turned on the 'change theme on url' you could try switching back to standard theme (add ?theme=standard at the end of the site address). If not, try renaming or cutting the formal_white theme out of the theme folder (paste it somewhere else so you can copy it back in later), Moodle should then go back to standard theme by default. Once you are back in, you can enable debugging mode Site Administration->Development->Debugging With that enabled, copy formal_white back into place and reselct as your theme, and hopefully debugging will tell you what has gone wrong. HTH - unless anyone else can suggest a more straightforward solution Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: No other changes at all... but I rebooted my whole system and everything is fine now. One of those Friday gremlins, I guess. Thanks for the help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change default theme logo in Moodle 2.1
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Formal white has it's own settings page where you can add the URL for the Logo. Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bootstrap elements and Essential child theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Derek - my understanding and happy to be corrected: 1. MoodleHQ has made a start on adjusting core code towards being bootstrap compatible, but much of it is also having to be done in a less file to override some things and change others. e.g. there is a large amount of work needed in a theme before a bootswatch can just be dropped in to a theme. But, there's a lot of code to change and renderers to create etc and at least things are moving in the right direction! Also, the decision was made to focus on Bootstrap2 which was in place when this process started and not move forward with Bootstrap3 when that came out. 2. Themes do not have to use bootstrap - base and canvas are still in the core - but bootstrapbase and Clean are now the recognised parent and default and most work is based on those rather than the older style themes, so it is highly recommended. 3. Yes, you can use bits of bootstrap in labels and so on to add bootstrap styles to your pages - but check what version of bootstrap the theme is based on! Clean and More and most others use Bootstrap2, but Bas has created a Bootstrap3 base theme which I believe Elegance uses as a parent. You will need to use bootstrap features suitable for the theme you have. Can you give any examples of the 10-20% that the themes don't do for you Derek? Perhaps someone can pick up some of those ideas and run with them if they are practical. R

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bootstrap elements and Essential child theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Derek, Embracing Bootstrap means making all elements compatible with Bootstrap. I'd say we are about a third of the way. there, and most things work. But it is plain to see that there is an underlying strategy to still embrace old styles, and not much going for Bootstrap now as it is old and outdated. I keep hoping someone comes up with a Moodlestrap that is Moodle's own. In your search for Utopia what is it you would like to see in a theme Other than the AwesomeBar! cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bootstrap elements and Essential child theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Re: "Embracing Bootstrap means making all elements compatible with Bootstrap" - no way!  You can pick and choose what you want.  If you just want to use the scaffolding classes then you can.  No BS components are added unless you add BS classes to elements / JS to add them. Re: "not much going for Bootstrap now as it is old and outdated" - Is it based on statistical fact or just your opinion? As long as BS elements are kept out of core in situations where they cannot be replaced in a theme then its possible to use any framework you want.  Unfortunately I think there is a JS file that does just that with one of the BS2 'span' classes.  But that's a matter for core to solve.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bootstrap elements and Essential child theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Please don't call me a 'Lass' just because I come from Lancashire. And no I am not laughing. I was referring to Bootstrap that is in Moodle now. It is out dated, and I truly feel it will stay like that, they can't update it as it would mean too much work. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embracing Bootstrap
ResponsesInList.Text: hi Derek, As you will see I have SPLIT this discussion from the Essential theme descussion, because that thread is in the process of being declared SOLVED, whereas this thread is likely to continue, and the two are only joined by a comment I made HERE . Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embracing Bootstrap
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Derek, I think that actually in this discussion that Bootstrap blurs the point.  It is just one RWD framework.  What II think is really the point is the desire to have an entity that makes solving problems easier if you are not technical. For me, Bootstrap is just as technical as anything else, it just adds components that mean I don't have to implement my own solution to the same problem.  Like re-inventing the wheel.  But, there is always a learning curve.  To use Bootstrap I've had to learn how it operates and apply it in the correct manner to the problems I've solved. There is no 'magic bullet' that will instantly translate words into complex solutions.  That's the realm of AI, which is still being developed. So in reality the simple answer to "It's how to deal with the remaining little bit that is the struggle" is pay somebody!  That's what happens when a skilled job needs to be done and you don't want to do it yourself.  A few years ago I put my arm through the ceiling - big mistake - but I knew nothing of plasterboard and how the fix the tile on the roof that caused the leak that caused the damp that caused the failure of the plasterboard.  So, I payed a good mate of mine who was a builder to sort it.  Far faster, better result and less stressful than attempting it myself. But if you are willing to learn, then "if a theme "Uses bootstrap" can an amateur learn a bit to do things" = yes, if you try, look and learn from examples, ask questions and persevere when something does not work. I.e. you apply problem solving techniques. Theme wise, Shoehorn is a child of Bas's Bootstrap V3 theme, but there are others out there, UIKit for example and I thought that somebody was making one with Pure.js.  Bootstrap is not 'the solution' for Moodle, it is just one of many possibles. Kind regards, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Embracing Bootstrap
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Derek, At last I have managed to get back to my own computer, rather than the iPad Mini I have been using of late. I think Q1 & Q2 have been answered, so I thought I would add my two-cents worth about Q.3. 3. My real question: if a theme "Uses bootstrap" can an amateur learn a bit to do things with bootstrap, like for instance the Filter_tabs? The answer to this is a resounding ' YES '. If you remember, I have written about it in the LOOK & LEARN forum post I wrote last year. The real beauty of Bootstrap is in the way it works, which in the majority of cases requires just simple HTML (most of which you can copy) and an understanding that the Bootstrap CSS that it uses to style, the elements you are adding must contain the CSS selectors for these styles to take effect. The 'LazyDaisy' theme I made as a 'prototype' of an idea I had, which works simply by using all of Clean theme's structure and settings but also allowing the Admin user to add a simple Carousel slider via the Text Editor (I use TinyMCE). By just using Copy & Paste predefined text into any part of a page, be it a HTML block or a Course topic, indeed anywhere you can upload images via the editor, in fact even those places where you cannot upload an image via the Editor you can still link to an image if you have a URL for it. Strange thing is I have never had any feedback about it to say it does not work, so I am guessing someone is using it out there besides me! LOL The TAB issue, will work in a Bootstrap theme if the theme has the TAB jQuery that allows the toggle between tabs to work. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: https is not loading my css on adaptable theme
ResponsesInList.Text: To provide support first follow the forum rules as already indicated. Then, provide more information about the problem. What you pasted is a random code not related with Adaptable. If the SSL certificate is installed correctly then Adaptable will work. All our servers run under SSL and we never detected any issue. Verify first the certificate is correct. Use https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest to verify it. If it is correct then follow the rules and add more information to help you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: https is not loading my css on adaptable theme
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, I had similar problems with Moodle, however I don't think this is a theme specific problem, more likely to be forgetting to change your Moodle site's config.php $CFG-> wwwroot where previously you had the site as http:// you need to tell Moodle it's now https:// for example: 
```text
$CFG->wwwroot  = 
https://
your-moodle-site-url/
```
 You may like to read this document which explains how to move to HTTPS:// https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Transitioning_to_HTTPS Hope this helps? Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Pioneer Theme - Remove Full Site Name?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello the title says it all. Is it possible to remove the full site name so it does not appear in the header and the header can replace the site name with graphics? Thanks so much - I keep saying it but I really do love Pioneer. Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer Theme - Remove Full Site Name?
ResponsesInList.Text: #page-my-index  .course-title { display: none; } #page-site-index .course-title { display: none; } This hides it if you use Dashboard or Site Home options in Moodle for the initial homepage.

ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much Chris.

ResponsesInList.Text: Development: Themes 2.0 is a goot starting point. Nearly every theme in Moodle 2.0 uses a parent theme, in somecases three. However I think the same rule applys. You can actually get away with a smaller number of files if you use a parent theme. ResponsesInList.Title: Autolinking E-mail Address overriding Moodle CSS

The blue from the autolinking in word overrides the autolinking links in moodle. Is there away of telling moodle not to let this happen? Your help is much appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Autolinking E-mail Address overriding Moodle CSS
ResponsesInList.Text: Claire: ***If i copy over a e-mail address from a word document and insert it into a course. My advice is "never ever copy and paste anything from your Word processor into the Moodle HTML editor ; if you do you are prone to all sorts of problems. If you must copy-paste, first copy-paste from Word into a basic text editor, e.g. Notepad, then copy-paste from Notepad into moodle. Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Autolinking E-mail Address overriding Moodle CSS
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Joseph, Is there a way of telling the HTML editor to tidy this piece of text up becuase it has come from word?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Autolinking E-mail Address overriding Moodle CSS
ResponsesInList.Text: You can select the text in the Moodle editor and then click the little Microsoft Word icon (Clean Word HTML); however this will not remove 100% of the nasty rubbish that M$ embed into your Word documents. As Joseph says, the best way is never to copy and paste from a Word Processing programme.

ResponsesInList.Title: RFC - Accessibility Proposal - Themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Below is my response to an important post from Martin Dougiamas concerning themes, from the Accessibility forum. Please post comments there. -- Hi Martin. Sorry to have got you concerned - I perhaps haven't been communicating my changes and there likely impact clearly enough. I will also post to the themes forum. I think you can see from Urs' comments that the themes issue is not as big as you initially feared. I have now used Moodle's theme previewer to quantify the impact - a quick and dirty table is attached which demonstrates that of the 15 themes previewed 12 appear to need no change - 80% success. The 3 that need some modification include the 'pda' theme, which would have need checking for accessibility/ usability in any case. Why the You are here using italics...? - I like compact markup, but in this case I agree it could confuse other developers - will fix ASAP. New arrow images... should use $CFG->pixpath - will fix ASAP, and look at filenames. (The 'em1' in the name refers to them being resizable - try Ctrl + Mouse wheel.) I'm fully aware of the need to minimise risk at this late stage and I will work with the theme maintainers. I hope this reassures you - comments welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Need to Modify login and registration process
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear fellow Moddlers, I have a small request.... I am setting up Moodle but want to tailor it to where the person is on the login page can be identified and directed to his section... Here are my high level queries: (1) How do I create different student categories ? (eg students who are from a business comunity, students from other universities, students from educational institutes and students who are just ou of H.S. - fresh) (2) How can I change the banner and logo on the main moodle page ? Much apprecite your help... Dr. C

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need to Modify login and registration process
ResponsesInList.Text: Not sure if this is exactly what you mean, but users can be sent to their My home page on logging in. Users can also be put into cohorts or groups and can be enrolled on the relevant courses in the relevant categories. Users and courses can also have specific themes allocated, so you could create a theme for each need and allocate that - alternatively it would be possible to build a theme which had certain features conditional to something like the user's role on the site, but making the themes for the user/course is probably easier as you can do it with child themes from the main one, removing the need to rebuild every theme from scratch. You may also want to look at and vote for this tracker issue which relates to hosting several 'virtual moodles' from a single installation. HTH Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Need to Modify login and registration process
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dr. C, When you say, "at the login page". Is this before they login or after? Before they Login will be difficult, however you could set a list of various categories for your users to click which would direct them to the required login page. After is easier, especially if they are enrolled and grouped as Richard mentioned. However this is all abstract thinking, you need something concrete to make this happen. So what mechanisms have you inplace, or in your mind's eye, to make this work the way you want it? How are you planning to identify your users? Cheers Mary

That format could include a css setting which could be pulled into the theme scss in the same way that the course summary file is used for course header images. I'm not sure whether that could be an scss setting and be able to make use of the scss compiling and variables, or whether it would need to be a separate straight css file. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme: Custom Style per Course
ResponsesInList.Text: One more reason to get better acquainted to (building my own) course formats! This approach is really nice because the option would be straight into the course. Redefining the SCSS variables would remain off limits for sure though. Since there can be only one transpiled and cached stylesheet per theme and the SCSS variables are globals, you just can't have different values in different contexts. I've slept on it and I think I'll go with the fourth: one child theme per custom look + allowcoursethemes . Sometimes boring > clever. (I've been checking out your Boost child themes: great stuff!)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Chameleon CSS edit window does not open for instructors
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes Eddie. As default only admins can edit the theme with Chameleon. In your Chameleoen config.php file you may set the option `$THEME->chameleonteachereditenabled = false;` to true to enable the edit possibility for instructors.

ResponsesInList.Title: Theme dependancies / inheritance
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey Moodle theme devs! I'm working with Moodle 2.9.1 primarily, but possibly also Moodle 2.7.x. I'm starting a new theme project that may end up being the base for multiple client themes. In the past I've just cloned my base theme and made any modifications as necessary, this doesn't seem like an optimal way to maintain the base theme and be able to push updates to the base while leaving any client overrides intact. This is where I believe Moodles dependencies come into play. If I understand these correctly any plugin can have a dependency on another defined in the config like so: $plugin->dependencies = array( `'theme_bootstrapbase'  => 2015050500,` `'theme_clean'  => 2015051100,` On its own all this does is check whether the following plugins are installed and have a minimum version. Then within our theme we can declare the parent themes like so: `$THEME->parents = array('bootstrapbase', 'clean');` How does this parents list work? For example the first parent has it's config file load, following by the second parent and then finally the current themes configuration, with any re-declarations overriding the previous? I'm interested in whether my understanding of this is correct and how extensive the inheritance is? If my new theme does not declare a layout for the frontpage, but the second parent does than will that layout be used? I've seen a command to exclude specific css sheets from any given parent so I assume all css used by the parent is inherited by default and any rules that conflict will be resolved by load order. Are settings inherited from parent to child themes? Are resources from a parent theme usable by children themes? i.e the pix folder If anyone has an understanding of theme dependencies / inheritance or an example of how to set one up I would be very interested to have a chat regarding it. My plan as I see it is to either modify the clean / more theme provided in moodle core OR have a new theme dependent on one of them that will act as my base, then whenever I need a client specific theme I will simply say that it is dependent on my new base. This would allow my base to accept updates from clean / more and my client themes to accept updates to my base as I improve it moving forward.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme dependancies / inheritance
ResponsesInList.Text: No...parent list in config.php is other way round...as in (parent, grand-parent) `$THEME->parents = array('clean', 'bootstrapbase');` Sorry but am dashing off... Catch you later! Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme dependancies / inheritance
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mary, one part clarified, it's a start! Another issue I was considering, If a theme has a parent theme and that theme also has a parent theme does the new child theme need to know about the parents parents and declare them in its own list of parents or is that handled by the system where the parent knows its own parents already?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme dependancies / inheritance
ResponsesInList.Text:
Just editing this to say that assuming you are using the Clean theme to make a child theme. Which is basically only a vehicle for carrying custom settings, renderers and stylesheets, it will need parents listing like so... 
```text
$THEME->parents = array('clean', 'bootstrapbase');
```
 If you then make the child theme into a parent then you would need to list parents like so... 
```text
$THEME->parents = array('clean_child',  'clean', 'bootstrapbase');
```
 Hope this helps? Mary Edited:

ResponsesInList.Title: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: I have set the default time for student and teacher but all the messages are saying they are from 5 hours ago. How do I fix this?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Odd as I thought this was fixed ages ago.  What version of the theme are you running?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Re-read the question.  Essential uses the server time as a basis for time difference: https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/blob/MOODLE_29/classes/output/core_renderer.php#L647 - which is the same time() function used in /message/lib.php.  Therefore the code is correct against what is stored in the database and so the teacher / student time has no impact on this.  Nor should it as the temporal duration difference has been normalised to be the same regardless of time-zone.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Good question...How do I tell what version of theme I am using? I am confused about your answer. You are saying there shouldn't be a problem? But there is. It says the messages are sent 5 hours ago. What am I suppose to do with this link you copied?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: By the way...I am using moodle 2.7.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok.... Plugin versions can be seen under Site administration -> plugins. The links are evidence that the code is correct. If it says that the messages were sent five hours ago, then they 'were' sent five hours ago.  This is because the theme compares the current server time with the time stamp in the database for the message using a server time function.  When the message was sent its time stamp was recorded in the database using the same server time function.  Thus there is no problem to fix.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme time stamp problem
ResponsesInList.Text: You are genius!!! I just updated the theme and it is working perfectly!!! Thank you!!!

ResponsesInList.Title: How to Change Doctype???
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I can't figure out how to change the default doctype to XHTML transitional from strict. (Moodle 1.9.9+ on Linux) I've changed the header.html for the theme we're using and see other changes coming through . . . but the doctype remains strict. Must be getting overridden somewhere up the chain. Anyone have any ideas? Josh West University of Washington

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Change Doctype???
ResponsesInList.Text: moodle/Index.php?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Change Doctype???
ResponsesInList.Text: I did check . . . but didn't see any explicit references

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to Change Doctype???
ResponsesInList.Text: It looks like the print_header function in weblib.php automatically runs a function called force_strict_header which forces the doctype declaration to be XHTML strict, so you won't be able to change it to transitional. Andrew

I copied the Clouds folder, changed the logos to say "Sixth Form" and uploaded the folder with a different name as the Sixth Form theme. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Two Different Themes on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Usually this is easy to fix. If you look at header.html you will find some path before images. Here you find some different ways to give path http://docs.moodle.org/en/Development:Theme_directory_guide I have used path like and it has always worked (Nameofmytheme is college for you)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Two Different Themes on Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: I use this as the path to images in the header. <?php echo $CFG->wwwroot.'/theme/'.current_theme() ?> This should call the correct header graphics in a course theme. jeff

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Two Different Themes on Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to make style changes that will not affect any the setting for one else in the Moodle.  Can this happen in 2.8.1 and Magazine?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't think so, but moving to Themes forum.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: No, css is not usually set on a per user (or capability) basis. However, it would be possible to detect the user's capability on a page, add a body class based on that capability and then utilise that to target specific css. Alternatively you could make a child theme which can be applied at a user level

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have asked about this "Child Theme" but have received no direction in how to. Can you send a reference?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah sorry Steve, just found your other post - I'm afraid I don't usually go to the installations forum, and Im guessing that Mary or Gareth dont usually either. There are a number of forum threads in the themes forum about creating child themes such as https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=187329#p815614 That's aimed at boxxie rather than magazine, but its the same priciples as they are both older non-bootstrap themes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: I wonder if I am seeing this in the right light. Correct me if I am wrong: Moodle seems to have two built in themes (Clean and More).  When I plug in Magazine, it is acting like, or actually is,  a child theme. Yes? If I were to smootzch up the Magazine, I can simply reinstall the plug in.  I am thinking I can also simply copy the Magazine folder and use that as a backup. Yes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: Clean and More are the main selectable themes in the current version of Moodle yes, but there are also bootstrapbase and base which are parent themes (but are not visible for selecting as themes as they are designed specifically for that basic parent role - bootstrapbase for clean and more, base for the 'legacy' themes such as Magazine that you are using. So yes, Magazine is in effect a child theme of base and yes, you can simply reinstall it if you make changes to it and want to revert to the original for whatever reason. The main reason we usually recommend child themes though is that should any bug fixes or developments get done on the theme you are using, you may lose all of your own changes if you need to upgrade. Now while that may be increasingly less likely (should that be decreasingly likely?) with the legacy themes, it is still a possibility to consider. Child themes also allow you to do something along the lines you were asking about - have a main theme for your site, and then have a minimalistic child theme that just has minor css changes for specific users, whether thats teachers as you were asking, or as I've used it previously, dyslexic students requiring particular colour 'overlay' or tinting to the pages. I used the minimal child theme to create 4 or 5 colour variations for dyslexic and partially sighted (hi contrast, larger font) users to select and this meant that more large scale changes I might make to the overall site (e.g. replacing the logo) would be inherited by the child themes, without having to apply all my changes to each theme individually. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: OK, clearer and more clearer as it goes.... As an instructor, I can have a child theme and it will not affect any other instructor on campus and now you point out that specific students can have their own child themes. It would be "HTH", if you could point me to how to explore this. Yes?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: In Theme Settings you can activate themes at a user level. Users can then select a theme in their profile page - I have previously set these in the database and used css to hide the option in the profile page when I wanted to apply specific themes, but didn't want some of the users (KS2 children in this case) to make changes. http://localhost/moodlemaster/admin/settings.php?section=themesettings So, the example I gave earlier: I created a main theme which was (at that time) based on my Krystle theme, but coloured according to the institution branding. I also created 5 child themes which had very minor colour/style changes in consultation with our student support services. These were essentially built on the mnimal theme that is provided as a zip file on the forum thread I linked to earlier. Several students were then able to make use of these child themes to customise the appearance of the moodle site according to their requirements. When I later needed to change the main theme to accomodate brand changes (a merger resulting in new colours/logo), I only needed to make these changes to the main theme and they were then inherited by the child themes automatically.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is there a teacher's level CSS?
ResponsesInList.Text: However, a user theme is specific for that user so will not automatically apply to a teacher's courses - the teacher will see that theme but his students will see the default site theme unless they have a specific theme set for them as a user. You can however, also apply specific themes at the course level if that is what you are trying to achieve.  That way, whoever enters the course will see it with the theme that is set unless they have an overriding theme set somewhere else. Did I totally confuse you?  Hope not!! A child theme is basically a theme that you create yourself and then make it dependent on the theme that you are basing it off.  You can make a child theme of any theme you want.  It is a way to adjust some settings on a theme that you like for the most part and a way to be able to save those settings/changes when the parent theme goes through an upgrade.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steve, As Lead Maintainer of the Magazine theme, can you tell me exactly what style changes you want to make when a teacher is logged in? Thanks Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: CSS is being ignored ... how do I resolve this?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone. I'm currently running a pilot project using the quiz module to see if Moodle can be a full-scale solution for some of our training offerings. I have been trying to change the behavior of the quiz module by modifying the . css stylesheet associated with the theme i am using, but some of the commands in the CSS are being ignored and I am unable to customize the module the way I require. Can someone please assist me in understanding what might be causing this error? I'm not fully fluent on the server -side of things (PHP etc.) so i'm probably just missing a fundamental concept about how stylesheets are loaded, interpreted, and applied etc. I pretty much have full access to the server that is hosting my domain , i'm just not sure where i should be looking to troubleshoot this problem. Here are the specific details:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: CSS is being ignored ... how do I resolve this?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Is your theme using the Standard sheets (this is set in config.php). If it is, then the CSS you are trying to add may already be specified elsewhere. To give your commands more weight, try adding !important to them. For example: 
```text
 



body {background-color:#00CC00 !important;}
```
 This would be a hack - as long as you're not making many changes, leaving this like this is fine, but if you plan to edit an entire them, then you should probably look more deeply for the source of your problem. Regardless, if this works, it will at least let you know that your doing something right!

ResponsesInList.Title: Using Colour Scheme specific Logo in Splash Theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, How can I use four different logo images for each colour scheme in Splash Theme? Suranga (I had raised this in an earlier thread , but no one seems to have noticed. So, I post it as a new topic.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Colour Scheme specific Logo in Splash Theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Suranga, Apologies for not responding to your earlier post. If you put your new logos in the same location as the old ones, and call them the same name (rename the old ones first) then Splash should pick them up automatically. Just make sure you clear the Moodle cache too (Systems Administration>Development>Purge all caches) Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Colour Scheme specific Logo in Splash Theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard, It’s OK, it’s my mistake putting it in wrong place. What you said did work. But, in fact what I wanted was slightly different. I wanted to keep the colour switch, and display a unique logo for that colour scheme, for example logored.jpg with red colour scheme and logoblue.jpg with blue colour scheme. I tried to find relevant codes in general.php, settings.php and sl. css ; but could not figure out how to do that. Then I tried an alternative trick by using the images, and it worked. I explain it below for the benefit of all. Thanks Suranga ** Here’s how to do that** There are four images for background in pix folder named lbgv2.jpg, lbgv2blue.jpg, lbgv2green.jpg and lbgv2orange.jpg; edit these to have relevant logo images inside them and replace the original files in the ‘pix’ folder. (Note that lbgv2.jpg is for red colour scheme.) Now you get the custom colour logo for each colour scheme. But, you see unnecessary text (your site name) over your logo image. That is because no logo image is defined for Logo in ‘appearnce>themes>Splash. Now, this is the trick. Create an empty png file (i.e. a transparent file with nothing in it), 230px wide and height of your choice (Location of your ‘Tag Line’ will depend on this height - try different heights and see, I use 160px). Place this file in the ‘pix’ folder and give its http link as the Logo in the settings page. Purge your cache, .... it’s done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Magazine Theme: Change Logo Size
ResponsesInList.Text: I am not sure if this is at all possible but how can I change the size of the displayed logo.  It is currently set at 300x80 as per the instructions on the Magazine Theme admin page.  Surely there must be a place where one can specify the size? Please help

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Magazine Theme: Change Logo Size
ResponsesInList.Text: The logo doesn't have to be 300 x 80, that is the max size it can be. So it can certainly be smaller. If you need more space for your logo, first you would need to edit core. css and change: div.thetitle {    width: 340px;    height: 130px;    float: left;} You would need to adjust the size here. Then, in colors.css you may (or may not) need to adjust the background position of the logo. So you would change: div.thetitle {    background: url( setting:logo ) no-repeat 0% 50%;} Change the %s to adjust the placement. Don't forget to clear  the theme cache after making any changes. Hope that helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Pioneer and Fordson: Can't install new plugins after installing the theme
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm a huge fan of Pioneer, having used it with Moodle 3.0 for over a year. But after updating last November I ran into a huge problem. I became u nable to install any plugins; my site stuck on plugin check after trying to update then database . I believe the most likely problem to be these themes. This is a pity as I love both themes. I had the same problem with Pioneer on 3.1 and Fordson on 3.2. Both clean installs with new database and no other plugins. My old 3.0 site had many plugins, worked with no problems for over a year until November 2016 I've tried all three ways of installing new plugins but always get the following error message when I try to update the database Coding error detected, it must be fixed by a programmer: The data source class does not exist. More information about this error ×Debug info: Error code: codingerror ×Stack trace: line 513 of /cache/classes/definition.php: coding_exception thrown line 515 of /cache/classes/helper.php: call to cache_definition::load() line 480 of /cache/classes/helper.php: call to cache_helper::purge_store() line 1737 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to cache_helper::purge_all() line 683 of /admin/index.php: call to upgrade_noncore() Can anybody help? Thank you in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer and Fordson: Can't install new plugins after installing the theme
ResponsesInList.Text: I kind of doubt this is a theme issue.  Can you install plugins when you use the Clean theme for example?  More likely something went wrong with the upgrade.  Are you installing the themes through the plugin system?  Are you using the latest versions? The error is referencing your cache - have you checked your permissions on your moodledata folder?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer and Fordson: Can't install new plugins after installing the theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Emma, Thanks for such a quick reply. It's good to know that the problem may not be related to the theme. In answer to your question. Latest versions of 3.1 and 3.2: I have reinstalled a few times. Both 3.1 and 3.2 were clean installs. Clean theme: I installed the pioneer theme and the board format using Clean and had no problems. After experiencing problems with Pioneer I reverted to Clean but as you thought I continued to have problems. Tjhsi is why my first Moodledata folder: Your thinking makes sense as I use the same moodledata folder for all my installs. If the problem is permissions on Moodledata, can you give me more information for checking these. I have whm root access if that helps. More information: I run my Moodles in subfolders of my wordpress site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer and Fordson: Can't install new plugins after installing the theme
ResponsesInList.Text: You can't share a moodledata folder between two sites - there is your issue.  The cache is getting confused.  Create separate moodledata folders for each site and reinstall.  Then see if you issue still persists.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Pioneer and Fordson: Can't install new plugins after installing the theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Alan, I'm thinking Emma is right.  Each install of Moodle should have its own data directory.  The easy installs from cpanel can sometimes point to the same data directory as it is a scripted install. Thank you for your interest in Pioneer and Fordson.  I don't believe the themes are the root of the issues your experiencing. Create a new folder next to the current Moodlesite folder.  Edit one of the Moodle config.php file to utilize the new data folder.  Make sure www can read and write to your folders. That should fix the issue of shared data folders.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Enough to make a cat laugh out loud...
ResponsesInList.Text: I wonder if we could benefit from an "Ask MoodleHQ" channel.  I'm noticing increasingly there are hanging questions in the forums and in the tracker where a quick reply from a dev could help a lot. We have hundreds of hours a week of volunteer time going into Moodle, and I think it is sometimes sad there is not a quick reply - even if it is "Hmm, dunno . . ." when you ask " Why are developers doing this? It's crazy..." Other times you know there is policy behind things, like the issue around ATTO, styles, colour and tables: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-45515 - but you don't know what it is. Colin has asked questions here.  "Why are devs deciding what we should and should not do?" I'm not blaming devs, because they would answer them if they noticed the questions.  But they get lost in 2518 posts a day.  Hence my idea for a dedicated channel. Good luck with your CSS fixes Mary.  I wonder if there is comment in the code to answer your why question. -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: theme campus not installing, debugging info here
ResponsesInList.Text: BTW , these settings are wrong. memory limit should be 25% of your RAM memory. Unless you have 8 GB or more this value should be reduced. max_execution_time could be between 60 and 600 (seconds). Now the limit is 5 hours to run a script. Probably will crash before by memory overload. post_max_size should be equal to upload _max_filesize These are recommended values. Only if you have some special configuration these values could be different.

ResponsesInList.Text: The Plugins Overview check is usually just a list of all the plugins that can be updated or in need of attention.  Perhaps the Campus theme you have installed has a more uptodate version available. If that is the case then upgrade it. The only time to worry is if there are messages attatched to those plugins with a 'warning' on a pink background, then you have every right to be worried. Sorry for thinking it was a GITHUB Zip file, it's just that the long name of the file made me think it was. Zip files form the GitHub do casue problems as the extracted folder does not show theme name correctly but uses the long title instead which makes any Moodle server "burp" and throw-up a load of errors. Well at least your theme is working. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I am trying to develop an independent variation of the OrangeWhite theme to work with our logo.  I've gotten the logo to work, but its height is 150px.  As a result the navbar, main menu and the other things at the top of the page but underneath the header overwrite the logo because the header height is significantly smaller than our logo's height.  Therefore, I need help with two things. Moving the "content" items down so that the top of the navbar is at the bottom of our logo (at 150px) and Making our logo a background image for the header so that the "You are logged in as..." message is at the top margin of the page. Please help!  I'm a novice at this.  Thanks. Mike Ryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: I think you will have to adapt the css in the file styles_layout.css in your theme folder. Looking in the header.html file will tell you the style definition you need to change (header-home I think). A bit of experimentation should get you what you need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm afraid I need more specific information than you've provided.  I already figured out that I needed to look in the layout css file.  But I didn't see anything that was clearly and unambigously what I needed for either of the issues I described above.  Nor do I know enough yet about Moodle to know whether there may be other places I need to look such as in one of the php files.  I have been experimenting without any luck in resolving the issues above.  Nevertheless, thanks for your reply. Mike Ryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok for No.1, in the CSS file styles_layout.css look for the following two entries #header-home { padding:0.7em 0; height:2em } (this is for the header on the home page) and #header { padding:0.1em 0; height:50px } (this is for the headers on all other pages)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks.  I'll give it a try and let you know. Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Alan. I tried what you suggest and it does work to an extent.  The OrangeWhite color strip that forms the background for the breadcrumbs and everything below it are moved down (based on what you said I've decided not to mess around with the background).  So that problem is taken care of.  However, this has produced a couple of other problems. First, my logo image goes all the way across and off the screen on the right instead of having a white right margin.  Yet, the colorstrip (see above), which is 1800px wide (my logo is 1024 wide), does have the white margin. Second, it appears that normally the login info and the navmenu and button are at the very top of the page on the right.  My logo moves them both down so that they are just below the logo. Third, in reference to the preceding paragraph, the OrangeWhite colorstrip covers up the login info and the navmenu and button. I've tried several different things in the styles_layout.css file attempting to solve the above problems one at a time, but none have done so.  What do I do to solve these (one at a time).  I appreciate any help you can provide.  Thanks. Mike Ryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Header logo overwrite problem.
ResponsesInList.Text: I seem to have found the solution to the problems mentioned in my previous reply. It seems that all three problems are related to the width of the image I'm using that contains the logo.  By editing the image and reducing its width to under 450 (it's possible it could be wider, but I haven't tried) the login info and navmenu are positioned where they normally are.  The problem here is that the logo is no longer a banner but a simple image with white space on the right where the login info and navmenu go. Using the cornflower theme as a model, I solved this problem by creating a table, the opening tags for which are in header.htm just below the <body> tag and the closing tags are just above the </body> tag in footer.htm.  I then used the bgcolor attribute wihin the opening table tag to set the background color to match the background in the logo image.  The result is that the header has the appearance of a full width banner that also extends down to the top of the colorstrip, which is what I wanted.  The first attempt had the background color visible for the length of the page.  However, when I set the table border to 0 instead of one this disappeared with a much more pleasing effect. Now, I only have to figure out a) how to remove the background color from the bottom of the page and b) to duplicate the colorstrip and the breadcrumbs in the footer.  But that's for another week. Mike Ryan

ResponsesInList.Title: More Theme - changing layout of the "Category" page?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Can someone point me in the right direction of what to change to alter the layout of each of the category pages? At the moment, when I browse to one of my category pages, the "Course categories" drop down box is displayed above the category description. I'd like to move it to below (or possibly even remove it). Is there one file that controls the layout of these pages? Cheers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: More Theme - changing layout of the "Category" page?
ResponsesInList.Text: Look in the theme (or parent if not there) config.php for the 'coursecategory' layout. But that might not actually produce the drop down.  In which case look at '/course/renderer.php' and you may have to override that in the theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: More Theme - changing layout of the "Category" page?
ResponsesInList.Text:
You could try adding the following to the Custom CSS settings... 
```text
#page-course-index-category .categorypicker { position: relative; top: 600px;}
```
 You can increase the distance you want it to display at. If you want to hide it use... 
```text
#page-course-index-category .categorypicker { visibility: hidden;}
```
 Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: middle-column widths

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: middle-column widths
ResponsesInList.Text: Rick, ".info" and ".summary" are two table cells in one table row. The width is defined in HTML not in CSS . You can't change this layout with CSS the way you describe it. If you want to display "info" and "summary" beneath each other you must change the table in the Moodle source code in the index.php file. I hope this helps Urs

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: middle-column widths
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes - I had experimented with this and saw that in the lip.php file I could change the cells to a single row and make it 100%. That worked.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Separate banners in Index page (front), login, Signup, forgot_password page
ResponsesInList.Text: yeah sure, if you need banners for all codes except the front page, just modify your header.html from your theme folder. In the header.html, you will find an option to insert banners for all pages. Now u will be able to see the banners at all pages except in the landing page (front page). if you need to customize some more pages without the common banner, then you have to edit the pages manually by changing few things in the code. say as example, you need to customize the signup.php page under the login folder of moodle and u dont want the banner to come at the top. Just edit the signup.php page and modify the code that comes at the bottom. THis is the standard code.... print_header($newaccount, $newaccount, $navigation, $mform_signup->focus(), "", true, ''); you will hv to change this to print_header('', '', $navigation, $mform_signup->focus(), "", true, ''); give null values for the $newaacount and change the banner for this page separately. See that it works, or else, send a reply, so that we cud discuss more. i am attaching 2 pics of samples. so that u will get an overall idea. one is d the sigup page without banners... and another is the inside page with banner. thanking you. Markkose Shiji Mathew.

ResponsesInList.Title: User theme improvements
ResponsesInList.Text: Background: When enabled, user themes can changed by the user in their profile. This is great where it is desirable to allow the selection of more accessible themes and to enable per-user personalisation but sometimes we want to assign a specific theme for that user and a sub-set of themes that they can choose from. In cases where there are users on the same site and branding must be exclusive to them it's not possible for an "administrator" to specify a theme for a specific user without them being able to select the theme for the other group. Although the themes in the selection list can be limited by the site admin this list is visible to all users. The course and category theme options work fine if each groups courses are arranged in that hierarchy but this is not always the case. Scenario: One Moodle siteTwo clients e.g. competing airlinesEach client has it's own brandingRequirement is that everything a user sees once they log in must be in their company's branding.Some courses i.e in the same category are shared by both companies.We want the user to be able to change themes to more accessible sub-set of themes (which would need to be generic for the entire site I think) but only to be able to change back to a default user theme that is appropriate for that user i.e. their own airline not the competitor.Alternatively if there is not sub-set they would only see the allocated user theme in their profile. Problem: There is no way (that I am aware of) to include user theme information in an upload file - this would need to be entered directly in the database .The ability for users to switch to any theme made avaiable on the site is universal. Solution: I think these are the requirement to solve this issue, I'm open to other suggestions... *Add the ability to select one or more themes that any user may select in their profile.*Introduce a default user theme i.e. one that is specifically allocated to them and cannot be changed other than to the theme in the globally selectable group.*Enable the ability to allocate a default user theme in the CSV upload process. I've created an improvement issue in the tracker for this suggestion, please feel free to vote for it and add your suggested improvements there. MDL-27276

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User theme improvements
ResponsesInList.Text: Personally I would have thought that in the scenario presented, it would be better/easier to have the competing clients accessing, if not a separate moodle site, then at least separate courses/ categories with their own themes. This, as I see it, would also make reporting back easier in not having to separate out employees of the different clients who have accessed the same course. Themes can then be set on a course/category basis rather than for every user. I realise this would entail some duplication of resources as several courses or categories may be identical for both sets of users (other than the branding), but that seems to me a simpler solution than the added complexity of potentially setting a different set of themes for every user - whether manually or through csv. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: User theme improvements

ResponsesInList.Title: Core renderer public function outputting simple array - any risks?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Everyone, I've written a function that produces an array to solve my problem from here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=356256 I have an array similar to: Array 1 image1.jpg 2 image2.jpg 3 image3.jpg 4 image4.jpg in my core_renderer as a public function and call this array in my layout files via: $patharray = $OUTPUT->get_imagepaths(); Is passing an array generated from a function via public method a bad idea? if so, why? I intend to then construct the path using the filename from the array in the layout page. Thanks, Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Core renderer public function outputting simple array - any risks?
ResponsesInList.Text: Depends if you can refactor the code to generate the output from the data contained in the array within the core_renderer, then that method would be public but the method get_imagepaths() could be protected otherwise no choice but public.  All depends on your OO design and encapsulation strategy.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Core renderer public function outputting simple array - any risks?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Gareth. Really interesting. The $output part of the function contains the results of a $DB->get_records_ sql call from a very basic SELECT query from a single custom table I've created. E.g. $results = $DB->get_records_sql($sql); $output = $results; return $output; Do you know if it's possible to refactor the $DB->get_records_sql call (or any other data)? I should add that I'm not using any other globals in the function other than db and all full paths will be constructed away from the filename held in the array. Andrew

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Core renderer public function outputting simple array - any risks?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andrew, No I don't but I always look to see if the data is already in a core object / variable / getter method as its likely to be cached rather than another database call.  Can you get the information you need from the existing tables or is it bespoke to your theme?  And see if you can use 'get_records' with an array of field criteria's instead of pure SQL. G

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Core renderer public function outputting simple array - any risks?
ResponsesInList.Text: When implementing new functionality, renderers should only contain code to output HTML based on the arguments that werre passed in. Don't do anything in a renderer method that you would not do in a template. When you are overriding an existing renderer, in order to change some existing bit of Moodle output. Well, then you have less control. The renderer base class controls which arguments are passed into the method. If you need more data, then you have to break the rules and get it. In an ideal world, you put the logic to get that data into some other object or fuction, so all the renderer has to do is call it. If what you are working on is a quick and dirty solution to somthing, then just put the $DB->get_records call into the renderer method. Sometimes life is too short to do anything else.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Making text change color based on hide/show status on teacher view...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Aaron, I added a patch to fix this which was accepted and is in Moodle 2.0.2 but a leter version of yours. The fix is carried forward into subsequent versions so it's in Moodle 2.0.3 and also in Moodle 2.1 when that gets launched next month. So my advice is upgrade to latest version of Moodle, which by August will be Moodle 2.1 To fix this on your Moodle site, just add the following to the end of Base theme's core.css. a.dimmed:link, a.dimmed:visited { color:#AAAAAA; } Hopefully that will fix the problem. ResponsesInList.Title: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I've probably got too much time on my hands at the moment, so I'm starting to look at adding bells and whistles to some courses (um... I mean, useful additions to the learning experience!) I've been looking at bootstrap and css snippets on the W3Schools site and have been trying out a couple. Some of the Moodle Themes state that they are based on Bootstrap, but others don't state this.  For example, Shoehorn labels this clearly, but Morecandy doesn't (though I seem to remember that Mary posted some additional code which came from there).  Is there a list of themes based on Bootstrap, or some easy way to identify this? A further noob question is, if a theme is based on Bootstrap, do all the Bootstrap functions (say, Modal or Popover) automatically work or does it depend on whether the theme developer chose to include them? What I'm basically trying to do is to avoid having to do a "suck it and see" test with every snippet in different themes just to make sure that they work in different environments. Thanks for any tips or pointers! Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, Please see: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=312844#p1252588 for a list of themes / Bootstrap version that I know of. With "do all the Bootstrap functions (say, Modal or Popover) automatically work", then yes it does depend on if the developer has chosen to include the JavaScript for them.  There are also differences between BS 2.3.0 (Moodle core - Bootstrap base and any other child themes like Shoelace and Campus), BS 2.3.2 (Essential etc.) and BS 3.3.5 (Bootstrap and Shoehorn). With "suck it and see test", then I recommend testing anyway as there could be a bug in the theme that prevents it.  That's Software Engineering, you need to test everything. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for that Gareth, My aim is to create small units based on a label that could be used on different sites.  Obviously, the less editing the better when it comes to transfer, and a universal experience is preferable.  I'm just trying to avoid reinventing the wheel while I'm starting up. Incidentally, the info which you posted in the forum thread would, IMO , be an excellent candidate for a Moodle Doc.  If the developers of new themes added that information as they updated it (perhaps with a column as to whether they supported the full set of Bootstrap elements or only certain ones) then this would be useful for Moodlers when setting up their sites.  They would know more about what they were getting. All the best Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: If the samll units you are creating rely solely on the bootstrap css, it is possible (where they are different) to add both the bootstrap2 and bootstrap3 classes - the one that isn't relevant will just be ignored. The complication arises if your 'units' also rely on the javascript from one of the bootstrap versions.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Andy, Just to put you straight Moodle themes (Clean and More) that are shipped with Moodle 2.5 onwards use Bootstrap 2.3.2. which come in the form of a theme called Bootstrapbase, that is the parent theme of bot Clean and More themes. That said, Morecandy is based on the More theme so by definition is a Bootstrapbase theme. We cannot say Bootstrap as Bootstrap come in different versions. Bootstrap 3 is different than the Bootstrap 2.3.2 that our theme CSS & JavaScript/jQuery that Moodle themes are based on. So to answer your question which version of Bootstrap are you referring to? The easiest way to determine if a Moodle theme is a BootstrapBase theme then look at the actual themes version.php as that should state what themes it is dependent on. For example: https://github.com/lazydaisy/moodle/blob/master/theme/more/version.php Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: A question about bootstrap-based themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah ha!  The JS might be 2.3.2: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_29_STABLE/theme/bootstrapbase/amd/src/bootstrap.js#L2 but the LESS is not: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_29_STABLE/theme/bootstrapbase/less/bootstrap/bootstrap.less#L2

Mary, I had forgotten the "base" bit on the end of the theme name, hence my confusing remarks.  I haven't got to the point of going about this in any sort of scientific manner yet.  I started by simply taking some snippets from Bootstrap 3 in the W3Schools site and seeing if they worked on my main site (which uses Morecandy).  I was quite pleased with the effect and thought that they would improve the learner experience. The idea is to create a "warehouse" course which would store a pile of labels, html blocks and so on which could then be imported into other sites and from there used in different courses.  In my case as a language teacher I'd be looking at bundling grammar explanations and similar stuff which is often recycled in  in a range of courses. The issue is to get maximum compatibility from the start, so I'm looking at what would be needed to cover all the bases (or as many bases as possible) to minimise the amount of tailoring later.  I'm going to set up an instance of Moodle with a standard theme and then a set of blank courses all with different themes to check the functionality of any given imported label or block.  Given the amount of work involved in setting it all up, I'm trying to make sure I don't overlook something obvious at the start. ResponsesInList.Title: Moving block from right to left, boost theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, What is the Simplest way of moving a block from right to left using the boost theme, even though all boost blocks by default are on the right? I'm using Moodle 3.5 Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving block from right to left, boost theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Following as i'm interested in how this can be achieved

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moving block from right to left, boost theme
ResponsesInList.Text: There is no way to do this in Boost itself as there is not a block region on the left. You would need to create a child theme with a new block region on the left and while block regions can be added as required (check out handlebar as one example of a boost child theme with additional block regions - there are others) adding one to the left side of the screen would involve planning what to do with the admin/navigation region - or maybe adding the new block region into that area, where the Add a Block block defaults to. You could probably add a region that pushes across, as the main region does when the flat navigation region is displayed, or possibly arrange it so it stays where it is and hides behind the pull out region. Whatever you decide to try, it would need to be a child theme rather than Boost itself, or you would risk losing any changes next time you upgrade Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Issue (bug?) when inserting js code in additionalhtmltopofbody
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi  All, We recently had an issue with a client who inserted by mistake this type of code : <script type="text/ javascript ">// <![CDATA[ (function(i,s,o,g,r,a,m){i['GoogleAnalyticsObject']=r;i[r]=i[r]||function(){ (i[r].q=i[r].q||[]).push(arguments)},i[r].l=1*new Date();a=s.createElement(o), m=s.getElementsByTagName(o)[0];a.async=1;a.src=g;m.parentNode.insertBefore(a,m) })(window,document,'script','// www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js','ga' ); ga('create', 'UA-19930415-1', 'auto'); ga('send', 'pageview'); // ]]><script> (notice incorrect java script closing tag) to site administration/Additional HTML/When BODY is opened additionalhtmltopofbody This results in a blank page all over the site, because of javascript incorrect code. The only way to fix the issue was to manually update the record into database config table for that setting and after that use moosh to clean the cache. Moodle version: managed to replicate the issue on: 3.1+ (Build: 20160609) and 2.9.2 (Build: 20150914) but I suspect the issue is present in any recent moodle versions name and version of the theme doesn' t matter I understand that we should trust content inserted by admins, but in this case as the purpose of that box is only to add additional html maybe the code here (admin/settings/appearance.php) should be changed from: $temp->add(new admin_setting_configtextarea('additionalhtmltopofbody', new lang_string('additionalhtmltopofbody', 'admin'), new lang_string('additionalhtmltopofbody_desc', 'admin'), '', PARAM_RAW)); to: $temp->add(new admin_setting_configtextarea('additionalhtmltopofbody', new lang_string('additionalhtmltopofbody', 'admin'), new lang_string('additionalhtmltopofbody_desc', 'admin'), '', PARAM_CLEANHTML)); Regards

ResponsesInList.Title: Some minor theme changes in 1.9
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, Thought it would be good to post a quick message about some changes to the theme code in 1.9 1. You can now set category themes. There is an admin setting to turn this feature on/off - it is off by default as it does take a bit of processing overhead. If it is switched on then you will be able to select a theme when editing categories. The theme will then apply to all courses in that category or child categories and the category page itself. 2. The priority of themes can now be set ie which theme wins when there are several set at different levels. You can set a variable in config.php called $CFG->themeorder (see config-dist.php for more details). By default it is set to: $CFG->themeorder = array('page', 'course', 'category', 'session', 'user', 'site'); Cheers, Shane.
