ResponsesInList.Text: I read fast that article. Now the question is, there's a way to include personal JS and third party script without create a module? I think it's a very annoing thing, i only need to include a library and use it with 3 line of code, in only one page of my moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using JQuery in my Theme:  Moodle 3.3
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, Depending on the Moodle version and the Parent theme you are intending to use (assuming it is NOT Boost theme), then you can add the custom files in a JavaScript directory of your theme and add the three lines of code in the layout file/s where you wish the JS call to be made. Don't forget to add the required setting in your Theme's config.php... 
```text
$THEMES->javascripts = array('mycustomjsfilename');
```
 Or this line if it's a .min file... 
```text
$THEMES->javascripts_footer = array('mycustomjsfilename');
```
 Where 'mycustomjsfilename' is the name of your js file. Hope this helps? PS: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=352246 Thus is a link to a previous post from last year, which explains how JQuery/JS works in Boost theme...!!! Mary EDITED to make this more readable.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot find the CSS file
ResponsesInList.Text: You need to perhaps clear the cache in your browser too, or try Ctrl + F5 which forces a complete refresh of images and files. Purge all caches too helps... Site Administration > Development > Purge all caches The Formal White theme is in the process of being updated bu becasue of a glitch in the process it was rejected and so is in for review/integration over this next weekend. I'm going to add this to Moodle Tracker now and fix it this weekend too...and hope it passes the review! This fix will go into Base theme. Also just a note of caution. When you make changes to any CSS, you need to add the new  rule to the end of the file. That ensures that any similar rule will be over ridden by your new one. Also creating a new css file is OK as long as you add the new css file to the list of stylesheets already in config.php in the theme directory. Also...and I should have said this at the start that you are advised to copy a theme folder and customise it rather than change the code of one of the core themes as these will be overwritten when you upgrade your Moodle site. Read the tutorial in Development: Themes 2.0 how to clone a Moodle 2.0 theme Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Themers, Looking at some core code I've found this: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_28_STABLE/lib/classes/component.php#L448-L452 which indicates to me that if '$CFG->themedir' is set then the themes in '$CFG-> dirroot /theme' would not operate correctly, thus a 'flip flop'.  But given: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_28_STABLE/config-dist.php#L372-L375 which indicates that setting $CFG->themedir 'adds' themes to the existing set. So.... which is correct?  If the latter, then there is a core logic bug.  If the former then 'no worries'. Cheers, Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: I may be wrong (or it may have changed since I was last doing anything like that) Gareth, but I always understood that if you set an alternative theme directory ($CFG->themedir) this replaced the standard one in Moodle core ($CFG-> dirroot /theme) rather than added to it - that it was one or the other not both. I'm sure thats the way it was working when I did something like this previously - but that may well have beeen as far back as Moodle2.2 when I was building flexi !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: This is what the config-dist.php file says: // It is possible to add extra themes directory stored outside of $CFG->dirroot. // This local directory does not have to be accessible from internet. // //     $CFG->themedir = '/location/of/extra/themes'; This is what theme/styles.php does: if (file_exists("$CFG->dirroot/theme/$themename/config.php")) { // The theme exists in standard location - ok. } else if (!empty($CFG->themedir) and file_exists("$CFG->themedir/$themename/config.php")) { // Alternative theme location contains this theme - ok. } else { header('HTTP/1.0 404 not found'); die('Theme was not found, sorry.'); } It looks to me that according to the documentation and the implementation that $CFG->themedir is a location for additional themes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: I am sure you have asked this question before, Gareth, or it could have been Danny, as he was the first to use that other directory which is part of Moodledata...at least that is what I believed to be the case at the time. Isn't this the reason you created the alternative $ wwwroot for fonts? If you don't know...then we are all in the dark with this one..lol Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: It's the same in 2.6 too...so what is the fuss?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: I came across the code, which ties in with: https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/pull/478 - so before I accept the patch I want to be sure I'm doing the right thing.  As it would be irresponsible to incorporate functionality in Essential that misleads the administrator into thinking that something is not what it actually is. Thanks Richard and Mary for your responses.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: OK...in that case it makes sense to question the validity of a patch for Essential.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gareth, I have just been looking at the patch for the issue you mentioned. Surely if Essential works in the normal way, as do all other themes, why is it not working when $CFG->themedir is set? It is, I suppose, questionable that there is an issue with the $CFG->themedir setting in Moodle core...??? Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Essential does work when '$CFG->themedir' is set, but the patch believes that "when it is installed in the default directory and $CFG->themedir is set" thus implying that setting '$CFG->themedir' is an 'add' and not a 'flip flop' as the Essential code currently works.  Hence the question.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary, the Essential theme does not work in the normal way.  There is some special CSS handling for Essential which overrides the standard way that CSS would be loaded.  Unlike other themes, where the CSS loads if the theme is located in either the $CFG->dirroot/theme or $CFG->themedir directory, Essential's code only loads the CSS if the theme's style directory is located in the $CFG->themedir directory, if it's not in the $CFG->themedir directory, the theme returns a 404 error. I submitted the patch to Essential to fix this bug that prevents it from loading CSS when the theme is not in the $CFG->themedir directory.  I have not run into this problem with any other theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Gareth, you need to follow that code and see where that value is used . They can't put both locations in that array when it's generated (without rewriting the code to handle arrays of directories for one special case) so it was hacked where the list is used to also load themes from the standard directory if themedir is set and doesn't point to the standard directory.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Therefore there is a logic issue here: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/master/lib/classes/requirejs.php#L80-L128 - with the new RequireJS AMD code where that 'hack' is not taken into account.  Thus with a structured walk through of the code it would seem that when '$CFG->themedir' is set that any theme with an 'amd' folder that is stored in the default location will have its JavaScript fail. That's why 'hacks' are bad and solutions need to be encapsulated in one place in an OO manner.  Distributing functionality all over the place dilutes the concept and leads to errors creeping in because something has been forgotten.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not fond of hacks either, it probably would have been better to use an array of arrays, instead of the hack.  However, when I traced that new code, I found that get_plugin_list_with_file eventually calls fetch_plugins (which contains the hack), so it looks like it should also get any AMD files from themes in $CFG->dirroot/theme as well. Just to show the path: fetch_plugins is called by fill_all_caches fill_all_caches is called on init fill_all_caches sets self::$plugins get_plugin_list uses self::$plugins get_plugin_list_with_file calls get_plugin_list (for not cached content) find_all_amd_modules calls get_plugin_list_with_file Similarly: fetch_plugins is called by fill_all_caches fill_all_caches is called on init fill_all_caches sets self::$plugins fill_filemap_cache uses self::$plugins fill_filemap_cache sets self::$filemap get_plugin_list_with_file uses self::$filemap (for cached content) find_all_amd_modules calls get_plugin_list_with_file

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is $CFG->themedir an 'add' or a 'flip flop'?
ResponsesInList.Text: Ta.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How can I add fixed menu items to the automatic menu bar?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hartmut, it was late receiving your message. In fact the first menu item of 'home' is a fixed one. You can add others before the automatic items or after them, but no embedded ones. In file coursemenubar.html you can find lines as following: echo '
    • '; $text = '
  • Home'; $text .= '
    • '; echo $text; print_whole_category_list_menu();     // THIS LINE PRINT THE AUTOMATIC ITEMS You can add menu items before or after above line(red) as following: echo '
    • '; $text ='
  • NEW MENU 1'; $text .='
      '; $text .='
    • NEW Item1
      • '; $text .='
    • NEW Item2
      • '; $text .='
    • NEW Item3
      • '; $text .= '
    • '; echo $text; echo '
    • '; $text ='
  • NEW MENU 2'; $text .='
      '; $text .='
    • NEW2 Item1
      • '; $text .='
    • NEW2 Item2
      • '; $text .= '
    • '; echo $text; If necessary, the menu root and items can be recurved as above.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme course categories and lists
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John, To get your list of courses etc on the Frontpage you need to enable Edit Settings when on the frontpage itself. ResponsesInList.Title: MORECANDY: Theme for MOODLE 2.9
ResponsesInList.Text: YOU CAN DOWNLOAD IT HERE... https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_morecandy Sorry this is a quick post as it is late and have only just realised the time. I have spend the last 5 hours fixing this theme. It's pretty easy to use. It has one settings page and is based on More theme. The only difference is that it also has a 4 column page in My Dashboard and My Public pages. If you get stuck adding and dragging blocks around the page just hit the Reset page button and start over. It takes a bit of getting used to. It has two menu types built into the layout. One that you set in Moodle as normal this will show up on pages after login. The other menu is activated via the Morecandy settings page. This menu only shows up on the front page before login, so it is meant for visitors and as such needs to be pretty simple so steer clear of too many sub menu items, as these can be problematic in small devices. One of the nicest features is the Carousel which you can add in the site topic area. Instructions are in the README.txt file within the theme and can be accesses from your site URL by adding /theme/morecandy/README.txt just after your site address, for example: http://univercity-of-life.com/theme/morecandy/README.txt I trust that will keep you all busy. Many thanks to all who have helped me with this theme. Also sorry for the delay in fixing it. Thanks an God Bless Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: BUG in Child Theme of Boost when deleting background images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Damyon, I have been working on a new theme based on a cloned copy of your child theme Photo . All seemed to work OK, including the background images. Super! That said, however, problems occurred when I decided that I only wanted the front page to have a background, so I deleted the others images and saved the settings, but nothing changed. The images still showed up in their different locations, yet the images are not shown in the setting page! All the upload areas where I deleted the image are empty, leaving only the front page image visible. Is this a BUG or am I doing something wrong? Thanks Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUG in Child Theme of Boost when deleting background images
ResponsesInList.Text: The images will still exist in your dataroot and if you haven't changed the SCSS rules that are setting them as backgrounds they will still show up. See scss/post.scss (I think I should explain that file in the tutorial).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUG in Child Theme of Boost when deleting background images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Damyon, Ah...that explains it...yes I see now what is happening. I've changed the URLs for the background images to use the setting notation that we are used in themes, so that the background only shows up when the setting is not empty. Thanks for explaining. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BUG in Child Theme of Boost when deleting background images
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mary or Damyon Could you explain how you changed it so the background only shows up when the setting is not empty? Cheers Sheila

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: structures of customize theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: There is quite a lot of documentation - https://docs.moodle.org/30/en/Themes I am confused what you mean by structure.  Each theme clearly sits in its own folder.  The documents that are not in a folder within the theme folder are those files needed to manage the themes on the site.  All themes, even the standard clean and more themes are clearly separate.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: structures of customize theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: If you are lookign to customise a theme, you should also look at the ReadMe file within the Clean theme itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: structures of customize theme?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, This all depends on the Moodle instance you are using, so knowing that there are many ways of creating a theme. But before we can help you we need to know the version of Moodle you are using, or intending to use. The structure of a theme can vary from theme to theme, but  generally look like this in Moodle 3.0. This is a link to the Clean theme: https://github.com/moodle/moodle/tree/MOODLE_30_STABLE/theme/clean And this is a link to the document Richard mentioned. README.txt I hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Give Binarius Fixed-Width
ResponsesInList.Text: Eric, Have you turned on designer mode or cleared the theme cache? Without doing this you will not see the changes even if they are made in the correct place. adjusting the width in #page in the pagelayout.css works on my local host . But as this is currently set to 100 % but the right and left columns are set to 250 px , you may need to be careful with any changes made to ensure the layout still works correctly. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Elegance theme - slider issues
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been loving the elegance theme, but have some issues with the slider. The images in the container, with initial settings, always stay at 100% width of the container and maintain their aspect ratio, which I do not want. (Nor can I imagine, would anyone.) I would prefer them exhibit the "contain" behavior which I believe would keep them within the container, maintain their aspect ratio and resize responsively. However, when attempting to make those modifications, I get numerous strange effects. Please note: I have tried numerous settings in the file here: ".../theme/elegance/layout/includes/slideshow.php" on line 145 For example, "<li id="slide1" style="background-image: url(<?php echo $slide1image ?>); background-repeat: no-repeat; background-size: contain;">" but also numerous other settings such as background-size: 100% auto, et al per other discussions in this forum. I think the error may be further up in the page at line 142 with  <ul style="width: 400%; position: relative; left: -200%; height: 415px;"> In firebug , this seems to be causing some dynamic changes in the css which causes misalignment of text and images (but not the dots on the slider!). Below is an example of the code in firebug. < div class =" banner has-dots has-arrows " style =" overflow: hidden; width: 100%; height: 250px; " > < ul style =" width: 300%; position: relative; left: 0% ; height: 250px; " > The second line left position % changes with each slide. I am not a programmer, so I hope I've been clear about this issue. Am I on to the source of the error? If so, how can I edit the slideshow.php line to correct this. The project is a bust without a working responsive slider. Thanks in advance for any help you can provide!

ResponsesInList.Title: Awesomebar changes help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: I had the same problem as Pascal Maury (end post http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=153801 ) but had added the Awesomebar to my custom menu in the Simplespce theme. So from 2.0.3 and 2.0.4 there has been a change in how the Awesomebar get's rendered as Paul Nicholls mentioned in his 10 Aug post at the above thread. I spent a day copying and tweaking the code from the updated decaf theme but no real luck. Decaf theme worked fine. I'm not a coder so can't quickly pick up the changes. Anybody help? What are the changes? I'll see if the Extending the Cusom Menu docs help Thanks, Al

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Awesomebar changes help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The problem with the Awesomebar is that it has to be adapted every time Moodle changes tack. And Moodle is undergoing quite a few modifications, in every area, including CSS which will ultimately mean that themes will be affected, which makes for a lot of work all round. The problem may not be so much with your Awesome bar but the fact that you have not got the most up to date Moodle 2.1.x (shortly to be 2.2) which need PHP5.3+ HTH Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Awesomebar changes help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mary, unfortunatley our host hasn't updated to PHP5.3+ yet but I suspect it's something to do with the coding in the Awesomebar because the updated decaf and Krystle2 both work fine with 2.0.4 on my localhost but my old code from decaf doesn't. The same blank screen happened on both my host and on my localhost with 2.0.4 update and the old Awesomebar code. Will continue to tweak however is the process described in the Doc's (previous link above) any more stable than that in the Awesomebar or are they just the same? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Awesomebar changes help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al, You can see the changes made by viewing an individual commit on Github (from this list ).  If you grab a clean copy of your theme and then start with the oldest one that you need (probably "Moodle 2.1 compatibility update" on 2011-07-06) and work your way back up the list, picking the relevant changes (anything Awesomebar-related) as you go, you should hopefully be able to follow what's changed and get yourself a working Awesomebar again. HTH, Paul

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Awesomebar changes help needed
ResponsesInList.Text: Great thanks Paul that seems a logical process

ResponsesInList.Title: media queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Every time I try to add a media query in CSS , it causes everything to display incorrectly. I am using the same queries as are used in the CSS (or at least as they come up in inspector), like: @media (max-width: 1199px) #region-main-settings-menu.has-blocks, #region-main.has-blocks { width: 100%; } But, when I save them in my custom CSS area, it doesn't work (in fact it seems to disable all CSS). Has anyone else had this issue? Am I missing something? FYI ... does it weird anyone else out that the CSS applies to both the back-end and front-end? From a developer who has used a lot of CMSs, I find this to be incredibly bizarre.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: media queries
Re: Moodle in English: Re: media queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Uhg rookie mistake! I don’t know how I missed that. Thank you! Interesting, I never considered the complexity of it as far as users are involved. That makes sense. And yes it’s my first time in a system like this and I’m in a fast-paced learning curve as I develop this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle in English: Re: media queries
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Alisa, RE: "FYI... does it weird anyone else out that the CSS applies to both the back-end and front-end? From a developer who has used a lot of CMSs, I find this to be incredibly bizarre. " - that's not what I understand by the concept of a Front and Back end whereby the UI is the front end (view) and the back end the database / model / controller, in MVC (Model View Controller).  So with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front-end_web_development and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front_and_back_ends then CSS is always at the 'front end' and cannot be applied to the 'back end'.  So I think you might be confused with the different views presented to users depending on their role.  So in Wordpress there is the administration dashboard which is the UI to control things, however it still uses styles that are used for the site, such as font, heading and paragraph.  Therefore Moodle is no different to any other CMS in this respect. Gareth

ResponsesInList.Title: changing background color
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 3.0.2 - theme More. I can access to every moodlefile and write in them. There is a way to set a different background color for each category (with all the courses in that category getting that background color)?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: changing background color
ResponsesInList.Text:
Ciao Luciano, Si certo... If you checkout the 'source code' for the page like I did here you can find the 'body class' of the category. In this forum it is category-3 see here... 
```text
<
body
 
id
="
page-mod-forum-discuss
"
 
class
="
format-topics path-mod path-mod-forum gecko dir-ltr lang-en yui-skin-sam yui3-skin-sam moodle-org pagelayout-incourse course-5 
context
-115 cmid-46
 category-3 
two-column has-region-side-post used-region-side-post side-post-only jsenabled has_dock has_dock_left_vertical
"
>
```
 So you can set these out in your theme CSS like so and there is no need to add body.category-3 { background-color: red } as these CSS selectors are already body classes. 
```text
.category-2 { background-color: red }


.category-3 { background-color: orange }


.category-4 { background-color: yellow }


.category-5 { background-color: green }


.category-6 { background-color: blue }


.category-7 { background-color: indigo }


.category-8 { background-color: violet }
```
 Hope this helps...

ResponsesInList.Title: Boost theme - help with Dashboard and Site Home page
ResponsesInList.Text: I've been trying to find which IDs or classes need changing in the header of the Boost theme's Site home and Dashboard pages, and I'm not getting anywhere using Chrome's inspector. How does one identify the ID's and/or classes to be changed if, for example, I want to: - enlarge the logo shown on the site home page - replace the user name by a banner image, on the Dashboard page I'm very appreciative of the specific CSS code snippets provided by Mary, that I can add to the SCSS box in Boost's settings, but I'm wondering how one becomes a bit more independent with this. Is there any documentation of the theme that lays out all the IDs and classes used, or am I just dreaming? thanks yet again. JL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme - help with Dashboard and Site Home page
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, The best places to look are in the Boost theme itself. So get yourself a copy of the Boost's layout and template files. you will find all the ID's and classes there. The CSS in SCSS format which is CSS most of the time but layer out like LESS in a more structured way but still available to inspect you will find this in theme / boost / scss / moodle/ To do what you want is a bit tricky. The logo should be easy to alter, however the changing the username to an image is not easy. For this you would need to alter one if the template files as well as need to write a renderer. To do all this you would really need to start thinking about designing / building your own custom theme based on the Boost theme. You can view all those files in Moodle GitHub Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme - help with Dashboard and Site Home page
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the quick reply, Mary! Designing a child theme is not realistic, that is clear; so I'll forget about changing the user name to a picture... As far as changing logo size is concerned, here is the SCSS in core.scss that seems relevant: /** Page header */ #page-header { .logo { margin: $spacer 0; img { max-height: 75px; } } } /** Header. */ header { There seem to be 2 or 3 possible logo heights at work here - so not really sure where to start - and then that rather sinister warning at the end about not touching anything unless I know exactly what I'm doing... I don't want to take lots of your time getting help if I don't have the capacity to use it. Should I just switch to a theme that has more settings and options that can be changed in the front end, and/or that perhaps has some support available? JL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme - help with Dashboard and Site Home page
ResponsesInList.Text: Don't worry about sinister comments, this is just Moodle developers making sure that these styles are not changed as Moodle layout relies on them to be there and in those formats. However you can get round this but styling each page differently so a fontpage can look different than the login page the course pages, the incourse pages, the admin pages, the report pages, etc. To do this you add the body class infront of the CSS you want to change. .pagelayout-frontpage .pagelayout-base .pagelayout-standard .pagelayout-admin .pagelayout-course .pagelayout-coursecategory .pagelayout-incourse .pagelayout-mydashboard .pagelayout-mypublic .pagelayout-login .pagelayout-report .pagelayout-secure In fact all these layouts listed in the boost config.php which is relevant for ALL themes in Moodle https://github.com/lazydaisy/moodle/blob/master/theme/boost/config.php#L36-L145 Another TRICK Try colour coding the places you want to change: #page-header { background-color: green; } .page- context -header { background-color: red;} That way you learn where each bit of CSS is styling. You can add all this css into the Raw SCSS box in Site-Administration > Appearance > Theme > Boost -> Advanced settings page. Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme - help with Dashboard and Site Home page
ResponsesInList.Text: This is great stuff, Mary, thanks! Have you given any thought to developing a course on customizing Moodle?? JL

ResponsesInList.Title: Theme error/query
ResponsesInList.Text: I've managed to create a custom theme for moodle using the base as a template theme for some minor changes (A lot of base has been overwritten by my current theme) however I'm having issues with the 3 col layout that moodle's base theme uses as default. I'm getting white space on the right of my screen even though there are no blocks there. I'm also getting the add block block popping up on the right sometimes (only sometimes) when in edit mode. Now Ive set somewhere that i don't want a right col in the back end of moodle but i don;t remember where that setting was as when i edit a block i get options of left and left for where it goes. My main problem however is when i edit my theme, so that pre and post are read into the same div (a float left div with content on the right) I get a blank white screen and nothing loads. What can i do to remove right column from inside moodle it's self. and what can i do about having the pre and post code being claled out one after another?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme error/query
ResponsesInList.Text: LOL... Well a lot of the people who help on these forums have been playing with Moodle 2.0 themes most of last year...so we are a little ahead of you, but even so, it's not easy to explain what to do, and as yet there is only one tutorial which needs updating. But it does explain things well enough. What you must do is make changes to your config.php in your theme's folder. This is what governs the way the page will display. You need to make sure the column you don't want is not listed along side the region layout...(see highlighted lines) Make sure ALL regions (which have sides listed) use the same regions as those I have highlighted here. (This in only part of the full list in config.php base theme). $THEME->layouts = array( // Most backwards compatible layout without the blocks - this is the layout used by default 'base' => array( 'file' => 'general.php', 'regions' => array(), ), // Standard layout with blocks, this is recommended for most pages with general information 'standard' => array( 'file' => 'general.php', 'regions' => array('side-pre' , 'side-post' ), 'defaultregion' => 'side-pre', ), // Main course page delete the ones marked thus Your next thing is to look at the pagelayout. css it's in this file where you will find all the code for the layout. You need to be very careful how you code the css as it is finely tuned. At the bottom of the page you will see a whole bank of settings for side pre only and side post only and content only. These too are important. The one you need to concentrate on is side-pre-only as this is what you are aiming for. Here are some links to help you style your new theme... the 2 column layout... http://matthewjamestaylor.com/blog/ultimate-2-column-left-menu-pixels.htm and the Holy Grail 3 column layout that Moodle Themes are based on... http://matthewjamestaylor.com/blog/ultimate-3-column-holy-grail-pixels.htm reading about the structure of the page is half the battle. YOu need to look at the source code for each of these links to get the code and the css. Happy moodleling... Hope this helps? PS: You might like to look at some 2 column themes in Moodle 2 core. Fusion is one such theme, all though it uses the right-hand column, but even so it will give you an idea how the general.php is set out with respect to side column OUTPUT php. Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme error/query
ResponsesInList.Text: Ahh so thats wherere it is, thanks for the help, allthough i still get errors and a white ceen when i try to stick pre and post in the same div to allways force two col designs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme error/query
ResponsesInList.Text:
You have to drop
altogether. You only need
blocks_for_region('side-pre') ?>
and in the head part of the page all you need is these two lines...delete the one with reference to region-post as highlighted below. $hassidepre = (empty($PAGE->layout_options['noblocks']) && $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('side-pre', $OUTPUT)); $hassidepost = (empty($PAGE->layout_options['noblocks']) && $PAGE->blocks->region_has_content('side-post', $OUTPUT)); Best is to create just one layout file and call it default.php You could use general.php from base. But don't forget to make changes to it as above. Then make sure it is defined in config.php for the theme, in Theme layout array... $THEME->layouts = array( // Most backwards compatible layout without the blocks - this is the layout used by default 'base' => array( 'file' => 'default.php', 'regions' => array(), ), // Standard layout with blocks, this is recommended for most pages with general information 'standard' => array( 'file' => 'default.php', 'regions' => array('side-pre'), 'defaultregion' => 'side-pre', ), // Main course page 'course' => array( 'file' => 'default.php', 'regions' => array('side-pre'), 'defaultregion' => 'side-pre', 'options' => array('langmenu'=>true), ), etc... Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Students Selecting themes
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi William, In regards to adding a theme selector to the menu bar at the top of your theme there is a quite work around you may like to explore. If you enable allowthemechangeonurl you will be able to construct links in your menu bar that change the theme. All you need to do is add `''?theme=whatever''` or `''&theme=whatever''` to the end of your URL . If you are doing it through the custom menu you will need to construct a permanent URL, it will work fine but of course your users will be redirected back away from where ever they are. Alternatively if you have your own theme and have your own top menu then I'd recommend the following code: 
```text
 



echo html_writer::link(new moodle_url($PAGE->url, array('theme' => 'whatever')), 'The whatever theme');
```
 This will produce a link that will change the theme, and in most cases take the user back to the page they were viewing. Hope that helps.

Seems the easiest way overall, although the menu would have been easiest for students. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Customize your course themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, This is a very exciting discovery for me that I thought I would share! I'm not a PHP programmer, though it interests me, and my specialties are more with CSS and XHTML . Thanks to Mauno Korpelainen for finally helping connect the dots to this solution . Designers can have this line of code put into the <header> tag below the other style sheet links of the "header.html" file in a given theme. Of course, putting it on the bottom gives it highest priority in the cascade to over-ride other themes. <link href="<?php echo $CFG-> wwwroot .'/' ?>/file.php/<?php echo $COURSE->id ; ?>/appearance/custom_styles.css" media="screen" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" /> Then go to the "Files" section in your Moodle course and create a folder called "appearance". Within that folder you can upload a CSS file called "custom_styles.css" and an "images" folder if you need one related to the CSS. Note, I put the course theme in its own folder so that it is easy to archive (zip) and transfer to another course. It keeps the course theme and related images separate from the other images in the files section. Of course, you can organize this however you prefer and change the URL in the <header> accordingly. Suggestions and improvements are welcome. I'm excited to have this ability to customize courses through my browser! In large organizations access to the backend code of Moodle can be quite restricted and/or controlled through a complicated software workflow. With this change to themes I will be able to make changes in my browser and see the results immediately with a refresh. This suits my iterative way of working as a visual designer and allows me to interact with the actual course content. Kind Regards, Ian Grivois

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customize your course themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Everyone, One of our developers made the PHP code a little more sophisticated so that it will not generate a broken link if the CSS document is not there in a course. '/appearance/custom_styles.css'; if (is_file($localfile)) {

ResponsesInList.Title: Essential theme: How to dim the hyperlink for suspended users in odd rows?
ResponsesInList.Text: The First name/Surname hyperlink is not dimmed for suspended users in odd rows in the "Users" table (Essential v 2016061716). Does anyone know how to I rectify this? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme: How to dim the hyperlink for suspended users in odd rows?
ResponsesInList.Text: Try the selector '.generaltable tbody > tr:nth-child(odd) > td .usersuspended a:not(.btn):not([role="menuitem"])'.  I think I'll have to add in a setting for this! Issue ref: https://github.com/gjb2048/moodle-theme_essential/issues/805 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme: How to dim the hyperlink for suspended users in odd rows?

ResponsesInList.Title: uploading themes

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: uploading themes
ResponsesInList.Text: From http://docs.moodle.org/en/Themes: 1. Upload your downloaded (or created) theme to the folder moodle/themes. 2. Choose your new theme from within Moodle Admin>Appearances>Themes (version 1.7 +). For older versions, the path is Moodle Admin>Configuration>Themes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Restricting Theme Visibility to a Specific Course?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it at all possible to restrict a theme so that it is only available to a specific course(s) rather than every course on the server ? For example, having a "Math" theme and wanting only the Math course on the server to be able to access it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Restricting Theme Visibility to a Specific Course?Theme settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes... You need to be Site Administrator to set this... logged in as site admin go to Site Administration>Appearance>Theme>Theme Settings>and select the options regarding themes which are presented to you in that settings page. The one you need to Tick is Allow Course Themes then scroll to the bottom of the page and click SAVE The page refreshes and you get a notice at the top of the page...Setting saved or something similar. You can not go back to your Maths course and with Editing ON you can update it to allow a Theme to be use for this course. There is a Moodle doc on the subject Theme settings Hope this is not too confusing?

ResponsesInList.Title: Bootstrapbase notifications in header

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Bootstrapbase notifications in header
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am assuming you mean the "Bell" & the "Message" icons? If so then YES...the easiest way is to add the same code that calls the function that adds those notification into the child theme layout file/s depending on the theme. This is the code you need to add. <?php echo $OUTPUT->navbar_plugin_output(); ?> This is how it looks in the Clean theme. https://github.com/moodle/moodle/blob/MOODLE_33_STABLE/theme/clean/layout/columns3.php#L58 Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: remove navbar completely
ResponsesInList.Text: You can use the JoomdleBS theme especially developed for Joomdle sites. https://moodle.org/plugins/theme_joomdlebs Also available in the Joomdle site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: remove navbar completely
ResponsesInList.Text: Fernando, This is great, thanks! Now i only have to remove the breadcrumbs and i'm set to go. Peter

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: remove navbar completely
ResponsesInList.Text: This theme was created for Joomdle sites using the wrapper and some moodle parts were deliberately removed. But it is not recommended to remove the breadcrumb because when you are in moodle you need it instead the Joomla breadcrumb. An option could be to remove the Joomla breadcrumb when you are in the wrapper page.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: remove navbar completely
ResponsesInList.Text:
something like 
```text
header.navbar {display:none;}
```
 in the customcss should do it, although you could go into the layout files and remove the <header> from there so it isn't processed in the first place. However, if you do that, you really should do it in a clone of the theme, or your changes will get overwritten any time you upgrade Moodle. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Boost: How to use Google font in .scss file
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi all, Using Moodle 3.3. I need help with the syntax to import a Google font into my Boost look.  Here's what I've been able to find from searching these forums (modified for my font): 
```text
﻿
$web-font-path: "
https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family='Roboto+Slab':400,700
" !default;
```
 
```text
@import url($web-font-path);
```
 I've tried putting the $web-font-path line toward the top of the .scss file with the other variables.  I've tried putting the @import url immediately after the @import "moodle" line. However, when I upload and select my file in the Boost settings, the site is totally hosed with no CSS used at all. Removing those two lines restores the CSS.  So, I'm obviously not understanding where those two lines go in the .scss file. Can anyone point me in the right direction? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost: How to use Google font in .scss file
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a known bug https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-57875 Workarounds: 1. Put the @import url statement in the <head> of a layout file OR 2. Put the @import url statement in a /style/ .css file (That's the approach I took in Waxed)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost: How to use Google font in .scss file
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi You can also, directly put the import url in the 'Advanced HTML' / HEAD section from site-administration. Then add a custom css to use those fonts whereever you want thanks! Mihir

ResponsesInList.Title: evolve-D version 2.0.2 released - Control the icons!
ResponsesInList.Text: I hope you enjoy using our theme, evolve-D.  With the latest release we've added a few requested improvements. https://moodle.org/plugins/view/theme_evolved Custom Icon Navigation - On the custom homepage there was 4 hard-coded icons in a navigation bar.  These were My Home, Badges, Calendar, and Courses.  These are now font-awesome icons and you can add up to 8 of them!  Just add the icon name, text, and link url. Slideshow - Many people wanted to see a slideshow included on the custom homepage. I am not a fan of slideshows but I do see a need to possibly draw attention to certain things from time to time.  I added what I call a "slideshow" but it is really an image display with nice transitions and clickable thumbnails.  Create 4 images at 900px by 300px and upload them to the theme Frontpage Settings page and you will have a nice visual display for your users.  All done via CSS . Improved Styling - Socialwall Course Format is another plugin in which we are a part of.  This allows teachers to have a facebook like experience within Moodle.  It is fully integrated with Moodle activities and is a solid course format for a social experience.  The evolve-D theme has special styling built-in for Socialwall and makes the user experience so much better! I even created a step sheet on how to configure and setup the theme: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1InnFyMfajEKF-MSfvSHFLYHFTLaiYxZ0nulVzJZ9OGk/edit?usp=sharing Watch the video on the new features:

ResponsesInList.Title: Solution to create a child theme of Essential that support a different logo/banner for certain courses and categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, For those who were not following the forum threat in which I enquired about the possibility of creating a child/clone theme of Essential so that I could customise a different banner for certain courses and categories, I attach the link to the solution: https://www.dropbox.com/s/4wqir85bwdveo3k/essentials.zip?dl=0 Following Gareth's advice: 1) I have used the /essentials/ child them which is contained within Essential as a subfolder, 2)  Within the child theme Essentials, I have created a settings.php folder containing the text: <?php defined('MOODLE_INTERNAL') || die; if ($ADMIN->fulltree) { // Logo file setting. $name = 'theme_essentials/logo'; $title = get_string('logo','theme_essentials'); $description = get_string('logodesc', 'theme_essentials'); $setting = new admin_setting_configstoredfile($name, $title, $description, 'logo'); $setting->set_updatedcallback('theme_reset_all_caches'); $settings->add($setting); } 3) Then in the file theme /Essentials/config.php  comment the lines: $THEME->parents_exclude_sheets = array( 'essential' => array( 'essential-alternative', 'essential-settings', 'custom' ) ); */ 4) in the file /theme/essentials/lib.php additing the part for uploading the logo from the admin menu settings of the theme function theme_essentials_process_css($ css , $theme) { // Set the background image for the logo. $logo = $theme->setting_file_url('logo', 'logo'); $css = \theme_essential\toolbox::set_logo($css, $logo); 5) and to use the rest of the settings from essential, we change the variable to true; $usingessentialsettings = true; 6) Finally, in the same theme/essentials/lib.php file we add this part to display only the logo (in my case I didn't want alternative text): function theme_essentials_pluginfile($course, $cm, $ context , $filearea, $args, $forcedownload, array $options = array()) { static $theme; if (empty($theme)) { $theme = theme_config::load('essentials'); } if ($context->contextlevel == CONTEXT_SYSTEM) { if ($filearea === 'logo') { return $theme->setting_file_serve('logo', $args, $forcedownload, $options); } else { send_file_not_found(); } } } 7) We add the language strings corresponding to the settings menu for the logo at themes/essentials/lang/en/theme_essentials.php (for English language): $string['logo'] = 'Logo'; $string['logodesc'] = 'Enter the URL to an image to use as the logo for this site. Should be http://www.yoursite.com/path/to/logo.png' ;

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Solution to create a child theme of Essential that support a different logo/banner for certain courses and categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the post Mari that demonstrates my guess: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=322405#p1294629 is correct.  Looking at point seven, you've used the same text as in the Essential theme language file, thus you don't need it and then just change the settings 'get_string' to use 'theme_essential' instead.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Solution to create a child theme of Essential that support a different logo/banner for certain courses and categories
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the final comment, Gareth. I will amend the language files accordingly.

ResponsesInList.Title: I uploaded new theme but not showing up in Theme Selector
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I uploaded some new themes by FTP and CPanel but not showing up in Theme Selector. What can I do?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I uploaded new theme but not showing up in Theme Selector
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Roohollah, This all depends on which themes you downloaded and which version of Moodle you are using. If you use Moodle 1.9 odds on you may have tried to upload a Moodle 2.0 theme, in which case it will not work as the two are incompatible. Same goes for the other way round, if you are using Moodle 2.0 and have loaded Moodle 1.9 themes, these wont work either.  There are incompatibilities on both sides...so... Having said all this your problem may be something else all together. So my questions are as follows: 1. Which version of Moodle are you using? 2. Which themes have you uploaded and wont work? 3. Which folder did you upload the themes to. 4. Which site did you download the themes from? Thanks Mary

ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Roohollah, Well from your answers, it is obvious why you can't get the themes to work. The two themes you installed are Moodle1.9 themes. These are incompatible with Moodle 2.0. CLICK HERE for a comprihensive list of current Moodle 2.0 themes available (other than those already in Moodle core). Aardvark-Lite and Gekko are the nearest to Newbury School theme & Premium. HTH Mary

ResponsesInList.Text: We are now at 1.6.1 and are experiencing this printing issue across multiple themes. When printing an HTML resource using the Firefox web browser, we get the first page worth of content and then a second page that only has a footer. When printing an HTML resource with IE, I get all of the pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: Sean, In Moodle 1.6.1, the only theme which does not present this printing issue is formal_white . Can you confirm this? I've found a workaround to correct the printing issue on themes relying on standard, e.g. standardblue, etc. Add this at the end of the the standard theme's styles_layout.css file: #header { border-width: 1px!important; border-style: solid!important; border-color:#FFFFFF!important; } Can you try it on your current theme? You may have to change the color of the border-color is you do NOT want a border to appear on screen, but apparently you need it to solve the printing issue. This is strange... Joseph

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joseph. I appreciate that this thread is now quite old, however, I have also been effected by this bug in my custom theme that was extending the standard one. The bug was effecting mozilla, seamonkey and firefox, but not IE. Thanks for finding a fix for that. I think this bug fix needs to make it's way into the main moodle code base. How do we/I make sure that happens? Regards, Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: please correct typo: You may have to change the color of the border-color is you do NOT want a border to appear on screen -> You may have to change the color of the border-color if you do NOT want a border to appear on screen

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: This problem is still occurring in moodle 1.8+. Any chance of a permanent fix within the standard theme? --Stuart.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: This is actually a Firefox bug - it cuts off floated elements that go longer than 1 page. See http://www.critiquewall.com/2006/11/07/fixing-firefox-printing-problem-tables . The right fix is for Moodle Themes to support print stylesheets. An interim workaround is to use IE to print long pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: I can't print more than first page with standardlogo + firefox
ResponsesInList.Text: Ack, I posted too soon. Here's the solution for printing multi-page tables. In your theme directory, do the following - 1) Create a meta.php file with the following line: <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="print" href="<?php echo $CFG->themewww .'/'. current_theme() ?>/print.css" /> 2) Create a print.css file with the following: #header, #footer, .navbar { display: none; } table, td { height: 100%; } 3) Edit config.php and set $THEME->metainclude = true; -Ann

ResponsesInList.Title: Multi Tenancy Theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Our NGO has not implemented a theme as yet.  We wish to implement a multi-tenancy theme for our Moodle version 3.3 that would enable administrators to isolate Managers and their respective groups from other Managers and groups.  The desired effect would be to isolate colleges from one another that share a single installation of Moodle. Can someone recommend a free Moodle theme that we could use or modify to achieve this functionality?  We would also be happy to collaborate with anyone to achieve the multi-tenancy theme functionality and share it with the Moodle community.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Multi Tenancy Theme
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fred, As far as I'm aware, none of them as that's not what themes are about.  They are about structuring and styling the page and not about user functionality in the terms that you describe. So you can look at the capability and role mechanism in Moodle to see if it will do what you want to do on one site.  But I suspect you'll need to run many instances of Moodle to have true separation and 99% certainty of isolation. G

ResponsesInList.Title: Apply the Klass theme to moodle mobile
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm a moodle newbie.  I'm using moodle 3.2 which apply Klass theme to our website but I could not figure out how to apply such a theme to moodle mobile. What I have done so far are 1) enable web service at advanced feature 2) enabled the web service for mobile device at moodle app category However, the mobile original theme does not take Klass theme when I enter my moodle site url to the mobile app and log in with my account.  I still see the orange theme in mobile device. I have read through this instructions in the section of customize your app theme .  I think the missing part that I didn't do is about finding a valid URL pointing to a CSS file and enter it to the field of mobile css file. May I have your suggestions to achieve my goal?  Thank you in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Apply the Klass theme to moodle mobile
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, You have done all the right things, however, the problem is in the Moodle Mobile App itself as you need to get the CSS ID & Class Selectors from the App so that you can make changes to colours etc. I do not think the Developers of the App envisaged the problems that the ordiinarry person doing these changes without good documentation, If you search the Moodle Docs you will find one or two that kind of talk about this but don't give you that much help. Here is a link to the question I asked in the Moodle Mobile Forum, https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=356166 You may be better to ask a question there and copy the link for your question here and post that link in your post in that forum, then you are not duplicating posts. Hope this helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Admin Icons
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm not sure who uploaded the file you've reference, but Moodle started pulling the admin icons from the theme folder back in ... 1.8.4 (?). My recommendation is to duplicate and use the icon set that is in the Chameleon theme, which I believe is based on the same nuvola set you want. This way, since Chameleon is regularly updated as a core theme, any changes can be re-downloaded from this set in the future.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site Admin Icons
ResponsesInList.Text: Alternatively, you can turn on the 'smartpix search' option, which, if it fails to find the icon in your theme, looks in the parent theme, or failing that the standard theme.

ResponsesInList.Title: Changing the colour of odd/even rows
ResponsesInList.Text: ...as title. What would I add to the styles_color. css file to modify the colours applied to the odd and even rows of the gradebook tables? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the colour of odd/even rows
ResponsesInList.Text: I haven't tested this at all but just looking at standard theme styles_color.css I guess all you need to do is to either change these standard theme tags or to add custom theme tags body#grade-index .grades .r0 { background-color: #ffffff; } body#grade-index .grades .r1 { background-color: #f0f0f0; } Change colors #ffffff and #f0f0f0 to any color you like.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the colour of odd/even rows
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. I've tried that already and it doesn't change the output of what I'm looking at. Using Safari's element inspector, the colour is coming from something modifying tr.odd, but I can't get any combination of classes and styles to affect the colour it's display as, in the 'Grader Report', for example.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the colour of odd/even rows
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok - I tested it and this looks rather complicated: /grade/report/grader/styles.php and /grade/report/user/styles.php override css in theme css (styles_color.css) if $THEME->modsheets = true; in theme config.php It means that tags like .grade-report-grader table#user-grades tr.even td.cell { background-color: blue; } .grade-report-grader table#user-grades tr.even work ok in standard theme css but corresponding odd tags don't - they should be changed to /grade/report/grader/styles.php Could/should be easier...

ResponsesInList.Title: Background color - work in process
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, i am trying to change the background color on my portal. i went to the config.php of the theme that i choosed(formalwhite) and changed this part: using the color i want(#231f20) // These colours are not used anymore, so I've set them to // bright green to help identify where they should be removed // These lines will be deleted soon $THEME->body = "#231f20"; // Main page color $THEME->cellheading = "#231f20"; // Standard headings of big tables $THEME->cellheading2 = "#231f20"; // Highlight headings of tables

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Background color - work in process
ResponsesInList.Text: Read carefully: // These colours are not used anymore In Formal White theme you may change colors in theme/formal_white file fw_color. css If you take from your page http://yolkmedia.com/CdRH/Conferences.htm following part from style tags and paste it to the end of fw_color.css (or replace corresponding tags) pages look more alike: body,td,th { font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; color: #FFFFFF; } body { background-color: #231f20; } a:link { color: #FFFFFF; text-decoration: none; } a:visited { text-decoration: none; color: #FFFFFF; } a:hover { text-decoration: none; color: #FF9900; } a:active { text-decoration: none; color: #FF9900; } But you need to edit not only colors but also layout (fw_layout.css) to get a good result.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Background color - work in process
ResponsesInList.Text: There are many "labels" but you could start from this tutorial: http://www.themegurus.com/css_chats.php If you can't find correct tags attach a screenshot of that part you want to change. Some css tags are different in different versions of moodle and you may find more tags from standard theme css files (with comments)

ResponsesInList.Title: Bad CSS?

ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Mary, It was previously: 
```text
padding: 0.3em;
```
 and later on there is the addition: 
```text
padding: 0 6px 0 0;
```
 so has been considered in the same file in the same change.  But logically regardless of any reset, then: 
```text
padding: 0;


padding-right: 6px;
```
 is just a drawn out long form of: 
```text
padding: 0 6px 0 0;
```
 unless I don't understand 'resets' correctly.  The single line padding just seems functionally the same as the two line solution to me. There is a bell in my mind that the CSS linter now detects this sort of thing? Or indeed it could be a typo (for 'margin') and therefore a good thing to question this and get it fixed! G

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: css style sheet
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tony, I dont know it by heart, but this is what i allways do when im looking to change some css style. 1. Look at the source of the page you want to edit (right click - view source) 2. In this source code, look for the tags u want to change. 3. Open a html-editor like dreamweaver... and search for that tag in css. 4. If needed u can alter or add css styles in the right page (the page you are looking for will be fw_fonts.css) greetz

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: css style sheet
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If your using Firefox , I recommend that you download the ' Firebug ' add-on. It's brilliant. It allows you to 'inspect' any web page and view its source in detail, including the CSS styles and where they are. GregE

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: css style sheet
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If you already have Firefox go to tools then add-ons. It will then show you what extensions you have installed. Click 'Get extensions' in the lower right handside. This will take you Firefox's Add-ons site, from there just search for Firebug, click install and then restart Firefox for the instalation to take effect. If you don't have Firefox you can download it at firefox.com/ Its free and way more powerfull then IE . GregE

ResponsesInList.Title: Splash Theme - Want to use .swf file in place of page-header background image
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I'm working on Moodle 2.0.3 Splash Theme design changes and would like to use a .swf file in place of the background image when switching inbetween colour themes. I know you cannot use CSS to do this and do not know php to make this type of change.  I have used javascript 's .innerHTML to change content within a targeted div. Is this a feasible way to do this? If so, would anyone please help me through the coding to accomplish? If not, would anyone guide me another way to successfully use a .swf file in the header of the Splash theme? Thank you Howard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Splash Theme - Want to use .swf file in place of page-header background image
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Howard, If you look in the file... base/layout/frontpage.php you will see this bit of code about a quarter of the way down the page. This is the header part of the frontpage of Moodle. It's here you can add the .swf file at the part which I have greyed out.

heading ?>

login_info(); echo $OUTPUT->lang_menu(); echo $PAGE->headingmenu; ?>
To add the .swf file you would need to add this code like so...

That's all you need. Of course you will also need to add some css in your themes main stylesheet. Something like... #page-header { width: 960px; height: 150px; margin: 0; padding: 0; } #page-header h1.headermain { width:100%; height: 150px; margin: 0; padding:0} The only other thing to do might be to have to enable a setting in Site Administration > Site Policies  which Allows Embeded Objects to you uploaded, this is a global setting so it will be availalble to all who are able to upload files. This may not be necessary if you have this files on a website other than your Moodle site. Not sure about the .innerhtml as I have never used it. But Moodle can work sucessfully with js scripts. You might like to read some of the tutorials Developement: Themes 2.0 you should find a tutorial which explains about getting JQuery to work in Moodle. The method in using those files will help you understand the logic behind JavaScript and how to use it with your themes. If you get stuck there are plenty of people here who can help you. Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Changing the login object
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Frank, To achieve what you want: a) in header.htm, display <?php echo $menu ?> b) to hide the language selector, go to Administration » Configuration » Variables and set langmenu: No

ResponsesInList.Title: Alternative Themes and log ins
ResponsesInList.Text: I believe I already know the answer to this, but thought I would ask anyway. We are a school that takes pupils from 5 through to 19. Currently we are developing our Moodle installation for the secondary and sixth form students, and so our theme, log in process, etc. are all geared this way. We would like to build in the ability to have the primary school section as well but their needs will be significantly different; with possible alternative log in options other than username and password, certainly a different theme, and (even with the same username and password log in routine) an alternative log in interface. The obvious answer is a second installation of Moodle, but we would like it so that the work follows through with the student from year 0 through to year 13 (potato prints to chemical diagrams of the potato molecule!?! hahahaha). Any suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative Themes and log ins
ResponsesInList.Text: So you can have multiple authentication methods and multiple themes in one installation.  I would create a separate category for the elementary and then allow category themes which will give you the different interface you are looking for there. Then, with the authentication, you might look at connecting a wordpress or joomla site and using Edwiser (wordpress) or Joomdle (Joomla) connection.  This would give you more flexibility on the log in process for the elementary and could then direct them straight to their category. Bear in mind that the username is what identifies the account so this needs to be consistent from elementary through 19.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Alternative Themes and log ins
ResponsesInList.Text: As an alternative to category themes, you can try our plugin https://moodle.org/plugins/local_profiletheme . This would help you if you don't have a clear mapping for category -> theme, but if you have the information which theme the user should get in a custom user profile field.

ResponsesInList.Text: Assuming theme based upon Bootstrap 2.3.2 like Clean, then popups in JS can be implemented either by: http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/javascript.html#popovers or http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/javascript.html#modals or http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/javascript.html#tooltips depending on the functionality you want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme: Custom User Menu reduction
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, This will remove that menu: .usermenu ul.nav li.dropdown { display: none:} It's a real shame that this menu is not an option as there is a simpler one in Moodle by default now. Or perhaps a simpler version of the menu as an option,  or better yet  an option to choose what items to add or not add, as the case may be? Thanks Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme: Custom User Menu reduction
ResponsesInList.Text: Essential is a timeless theme that resists the whims of the moment to provide a consistent progressional solution that is different from the run of the mill.  Thus the user menu will remain as is with its adaptive code to add items if the given capability / option is validated. Therefore there are mechanisms by which it can be improved / customised: Do it yourself with the source code provided. Pay me to make the enhancement if you don't have the skills. I decide that it is a technique I've not done before and wish to learn something new. The choice is yours, that's the beauty of open source, you have a choice.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme: Custom User Menu reduction

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme: Custom User Menu reduction
ResponsesInList.Text: You can try adding the following into the Custom CSS section of Essential settings page .navbar .navbar-inner .usermenu {  display: none; }

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential Theme: Custom User Menu reduction

See my reply to your other post about using Mary's How to Clone a Theme document and also the links at the bottom of that page such as Creating your first theme . ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Essential theme - moodle 3.0
ResponsesInList.Text: First try turning debugging on... Site administration > Development > Debugging Set this to DEVELOPER mode. Then click SAVE SETTINGS Next go to the Frontpage and see if you get any errors. Server errors are basically one system not talking to another. So Moodle is not talking to the server...or the Server cant find the database. So check you have all the correct url locations in the root config.php.

ResponsesInList.Title: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I'm hoping somebody can help me... I downloaded and installed the "Online University" theme from Themza for a brand new installation of moodle. There are a couple of bugs and as I now discover Themza offer neither help nor a forum where people can swap fixes, I hope someone here can tell me how to shift them. First, in the top right corner of the screen there are the "You are logged in as 'user' 'log in/out' links. Both are a relatively standard blue. Problem is, so is the background. The colours aren't identical, but close enough to be invisible to me. I downloaded the relevant css file and played around with the colours for the a: links until I decided on a not too garish shade of orange so that the links were separated both from the background and the white text that precedes the log-in text. Then I noticed the blatantly obvious....that it had changed colour of pretty much everything else on the page (how many links are in each course page....?). So, back to square one. The log-in shows at the top of each and every page. How can I change the colour of just the log-in links in the header? Anybody? If you give advice, please make it simple because that's what I am too...so spell it out in capital letters with lots of pictures.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Brian, I'll help all I can, but not having the theme to hand is a drawback, but having said that here are some pointers anyway. When styling/customising a theme, changing some of the Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a good place to start, as most things can be done this way, within reason that is. If you use Firefox as a browser you can get an Add-on called Firebug . Firebug is an excellent tool for finding out which bit of CSS code you need to either change or add to your existing style sheet (stylesheets have .css as their file-name extension). OK...on to your questions. 1: look for .headermenu in your css file for the theme you want to change. If you cannot find it, add it to the end of the css file. Here's the bit of code you need to add if it's not there already...I've added the names of the colors as orange for the link, and ivory for the hover, you can change these to suit your site. .headermenu .logininfo a:link, .headermenu .logininfo a:visited { color: orange; text-decoration: none; } .headermenu .logininfo a:hover, .headermenu .logininfo a:active { color: ivory; text-decoration: none; } 2: The problem with the logos will be generated from whatever code there is in the footer.html file. It's difficult to explain, although it is relatively easy to fix with an experienced eye for these things, it becomes all the more difficult to explain when one cannot see the footer.html file. So if you could upload this file in your next comment, that would be a good start. Note on how to upload a file: At the bottom of the page, where you add your reply, you should see a section which allows you to attach a file (be it an image or a small text file) you can upload the footer.html file from there. Just use the brows button to browse the files in your computer to locate the footer.html in your theme's folder. Select it and it then just CLICK the button marked Post to forum Hope this all helps? Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Thanks for the reply - most helpful. I'm busy this morning so I'll play with the instructions you gave me this afternoon and see if I can't work it out for myself how to fix the rest. I've got Firebug but haven't had time to learn how to use it yet. I seem to have picked up more software than I'd need to build a space station recently.. I did a search for Themza templates and came across several posts which came part-way to solving some of the issues. Seems Themza put fake gifs and code into their templates to generate links and, I presume, some form of advertising for themselves. I've deleted most of that. In doing so, the themza logos vanished. However, there are still some bugs so I will persist. Thanks for your help. Brian

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Brian, I ended up downloading the University Themza theme you are using as I did not know how they set the links. To remove the links altogether you need to take out some code from both the header.html & footer.html files. It's quite clever how their links work. The images are not fake they are hotlinked from Themza's own website, so every time anyone enters your website, either as a visitor or as a member of staff, or a student, then Themza knows about it, as it will be logged in their web stats. It you would like to know how to take those links off your site let me know your email in a private message, and I'll email you the cleaned up header & footer. Cheers Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: Mary, you can give people public advice as well - those Themza themes are GPL themes ... http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=152645#p668053

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Problem with invisible links...
ResponsesInList.Text: In my theme directory, whilst trying to track down where to change colours or the 'logged in as..' text I noticed a file called .wysiwygPro_preview_57864b256b9cbcc447ad6e28b7a55608.php It seemed an odd name and it was the only file I hadn't read so... inside I found this text: php if ($_GET['randomId'] != "Bt7I4PEdx3H8Js8oa7LZwDUQ18_o6ztQhnLcxYCJl1HXZGrUanXXdlYZSE6OLwfb") { echo "Access Denied"; exit(); } // display the HTML code: echo stripslashes($_POST['wproPreviewHTML']); I deleted the opening and closing symbols in case I'm not allowed to post complete bits of code. Otherwise, it's complete. Brian

Mary

ResponsesInList.Title: Theme for one module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, once again I've got a question. I'm trying to add a specific theme to just a module. Is this actually possible? Because what I'm trying to do is just to programm one module. Which can be given to other people. I'd just like it to be my own theme. I hope this is possible in any way. Thank you in advance for any help. Fabio

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme for one module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fabio, In Theme Settings (Site Administration>Appearance>Themes>Theme Settings) you can activate the ability to set a speecific theme for a course, or by url. Either of these may be appropriate for your needs - you could include the theme in the url, or if you turn on the course themes, then you can force the theme in the course settings page. Richard

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme for one module

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Theme for one module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Fabio, When you say 'module' are you talking about a plugin mod or setting up a specific course to use a theme? If you just mean you want a plugin mod to be styled in a certain way then you can do that within the mod by adding CSS to style.css which is in the mod folder. If however you are talking about wanting to set a theme for a specific course or category then the method Richard talks about is what you need to do. HTH Mary
